This is our story The story of a young Muslim immigrant from the council estate taking on Prime Minister Boris Johnson Across the Western world people are desperate for a radical shift in the kinds of politics and politicians that they are presented with Primary defeats to established figures and shock results in referendums are becoming the norm while outsiders are shaking up political cultures In this book Ali Milani a rising star in the UK s Labour Party brings a unique perspective on the key political issues we are now facing in the wake of the COVID pandemic to show how young people from different backgrounds can engage in politics Using his rollercoaster campaign against Prime Minister Boris Johnson in the UK s general election and his time in Bernie Sanders campaign team he inspires a new generation of political leaders from the disenfranchised disillusioned and marginalised to usher in a new wave of diverse voices and experience in mainstream politics

About Dumpstaphunk Dumpstaphunk stands out amongst New Orleans best cementing themselves as one of the funkiest bands to ever arise from the Crescent City Born on the Jazz Heritage Festival stage and descended from Neville and Meters family bloodlines these soldiers of funk ignite a deep gritty groove that dares listeners not to move Their performances combine ingenious musicianship through complex funk rock and jazz arrangements accompanied by soulful melodies and Big Easy traditions The band just released their th studio album Where Do We Go From Here on April featuring Marcus King Trombone Shorty and Chali Na and is now available on double bronze vinyl CD and all digital platforms Dumpstaphunk culled material from many different sources over the past few years creating during downtime and rare off tour cycle stop gaps at various studios in New Orleans some songs were born on the spot in the studio others as a drum beat or a groove at sound check A few were simply covers that were already in the band s live repertoire The songwriting was largely collaborative with all band members contributing their own respective stylistic nuances For the past years Dumpstaphunk has earned its reputation as the most well regarded next generation New Orleans live powerhouse the type of band whose live shows attract sit ins from legends like Carlos Santana Bob Weir and Trombone Shorty Alongside Hall Daniels Alex Wasily Ryan Nyther and drummer Deven Trusclair cousins Ivan and Ian Neville have built upon their family s iconic NOLA legacy as they ve transformed Dumpstaphunk into the city s pre eminent st century funk fusion export resulting in recent career highlights like their July opening gig for the Rolling Stones on their home turf at the Superdome Dueling baselines from Tony Hall and Nick Daniels III set off one of the dirtiest rhythm sections on the planet while Ivan Neville lights up the Hammond B keys and cousin Ian Neville s funky guitar riffs send the groove into overdrive Dumpstaphunk tosses around lead vocals and four part harmonies the way Sly the Family Stone did but with three studio albums under their belt Dumpstaphunk stands on the merit of their own material Dumpstaphunk has performed at the New Orleans Jazz Heritage Festival every year since and continues to tour all over the world Most recently before the pandemic the band supported The Rolling Stones in New Orleans as well as toured with George Clinton The Parliament Funkadelic for his farewell tour They have performed on hundreds of festival stages likeJamCruise Dead Company s Playing in the Sand Lockn Festival NYC s Summerstage and Byron Bay Bluesfest and you never know who may appear as a guest on stage with the band on any given night Guest appearances have included Santana Bob Weir John Oates Lucas Nelson Deen Ween Blackbyrd McKnight Jerry Harrison Marcus King and Nicki Bluhm DUMPSTAPHUNK is Ivan Neville keyboards vocals Tony Hall bass guitar vocals Ian Neville guitar Nick Daniels III bass vocals Deven Trusclair drums Alex Wasily trombone Ryan Nyther trumpet DISCOGRAPY Where Do We Go From Here April Dirty Word Everybody Want Sum Listen Hear

MFP alumna and indigenous nurse scientist Dr Eugenia Isabel Flores Millender explains how trauma can become infused in the genetic make up of marginalized communities Dr Millender s cutting edge research seeks to identify the key to reversing inherited trauma and thereby improve health outcomes for historically marginalized communities Every societal shock from environmental disasters to economic downturns to public health emergencies like the COVID pandemic take a far greater toll on minority communities The Minority Fellowship Program at the American Nurses Association is the only federal program supporting nurses from all racial and ethnic minorities with graduate fellowships focused on the specialty of psychiatric mental health and substance use If you are passionate about improving the psychiatric and mental health outcomes of marginalized communities apply now at or contact us at mfp ana org Listen to the entire episode on Indigenous Nurse Scientists at

I am Triple Jabbed and I believe vaccines work and the Covid Vaccines have been extremely helpful and credit to the British People for having the highest uptake of vaccinations in OECD countries But I have serious reservations about mandatory vaccinations I do not support Govt s policy of mandatory NHS vaccination and more importantly the narrative Sajid Javid is pushing in order to force through this policy My reasons are as follows Informed Consent is a core pillar of modern medical ethics It took over years to be developed after analysing through the atrocities of the Holocaust that were specifically committed in the name of medical experiments To undermine informed consent would be to undermine modern medicinal practice Will we be making treatment for mandatory for Hep B and HIV as those pose a huge threat to the public as well This narrative that Sajid Javid has used about unvaccinated staff posing a danger to patients has NO substantial data behind it and he being a politician sat with his media advisors after getting owned by Dr Steve James and came up with this line That interaction was almost the end for his hopes of leading the Conservative Party someday and he had to come out in the media with a counter narrative I have many colleagues who are not vaccinated but are some of the most dedicated healthcare professionals The idea that all these staff are now a danger to patients when they were all a blessing in the first lockdown with no vaccines reeks of hypocrisy I do medicine and politics and my experience in public health has taught me both are intertwined but this narrative is full of pitfalls and can erode public trust in medical staff The above two reasons should be good enough to pause and cancel the introduction of mandatory vaccination irrespective of job profile With the waiting list so long will losing valuable trained and dedicated staff help in any way If we are opening the country up again people then can catch Covid from anyone What is the whole point of making a scapegoat out of Healthcare professionals Could you not get Covid from the cashier at the till or someone serving you at a restaurant or a bar The UK is introducing Paxlovid from February the drug which can reduce hospitalisation and deaths by if infected with Covid Why are we then introducing such draconian measures for NHS staff This govt policy must have a review I know the whole political spectrum is busy with one thing only right now but we must not ignore the ramifications once this policy is implemented I have no problem with an annual Covid vaccine although we must be careful about vaccine fatigue if we introduce weekly vaccines which one company once suggested if i am not mistaken Before any idiot tries to portray me as anti vax I was completely vaccinated according to WHO guidelines while growing up in Bangladesh and before starting for the NHS I had voluntarily got vaccinated with the additional ones I was eligible for at the time as UK has an expanded vaccination programme and for the last years I have diligently taken all my flu vaccines annually I am as pro vaccination as anyone can get but I do not believe in compulsion Pro vaccination should not mean mandatory vaccination If I supported mandatory vaccinations I would have gone to China not the West Please CancelMandatoryVaccination Say NoToMandatoryVaccination

Closed Door Back Room Deals At City Hall Must End Well this is interesting First off I want you to look at the letters in red at the top of the first page of this document ALDERMEN CONFIDENTIAL closed record This document was never meant to be revealed to the citizens of Parkville Why is that Well I have a few questions Why is the Board of Aldermen planning to build a new luxury apartment complex next to the river inside a floodplain Why are they using the same development firm that destroyed Kansas City s formerly beautiful Berkley Riverfront Park Does the Board of Aldermen think they re spending Monopoly money What will be the impact on English Landing Park and Platte Landing Park What will be the impact of extra traffic on Downtown Parkville Will this benefit the community as a whole or will it just make an already wealthy developer even more wealthy Implications of building this apartment complex inside a floodplain Information from a current Parkville resident Flooding is generally the most common and costliest type of disaster Missouri experiences but standard homeowner s insurance does not cover flooding so it s important to have protection from damage associated with flooding SEMA s Floodplain Management Section administers the National Flood Insurance Program NFIP for the state of Missouri NFIP offers flood insurance to homeowners renters and business owners if their community participates in the program providing more than billion in flood insurance coverage for Missouri homes and business annually Participating communities agree to adopt and enforce floodplain management ordinances that meet or exceed FEMA requirements So the long and short of it is Parkville taxpayers you and me will have to pay in added taxes for flood insurance Impact on Parkville s parks If you remember Berkley Park in Kansas City before Flaherty Collins came in and covered it with apartments it was a large beautiful park on the river with many events festivals concerts etc It was a place where people could gather with their families Now nothing really happens there The only use is for people to walk the river trail Is this what we want for English Landing Park and Platte Landing Park I think not Impact on the businesses in Downtown Parkville Traffic coming through Downtown Parkville can already be congested This new stack em pack em apartment complex would turn downtown and the roads leading into it into a virtual parking lot The businesses there are already struggling trying to come out of the COVID restrictions placed on them by the County Health Board Deterring shoppers from coming into Downtown by creating huge traffic blockages would put the final nail in the coffin for them This is just common sense Anyone can see that except our Board of Aldermen Or maybe they do see it and they just don t care Benefit to the community So the citizens of Parkville will be on the hook for in increased taxes It will ruin English Landing Park and Platte Landing Park That means no more events downtown Parkville Days gone Fourth of July events gone Parkville Microbrew Festival gone Downtown shopping gone These all promote and bring people into the city to spend money Also how does providing the developer Flaherty Collins million million in incentives to build this monstrosity benefit the community as a whole The answer It doesn t So why would the Board of Aldermen even consider this plan And why would they want to keep it secret What else is City Hall hiding from us This is a prime example of why we need a change in City Hall This is why we need to be in the room when these things are being discussed This is why there should be NO private confidential meetings When it comes to issues that are going to have a massive impact on the community and businesses of the city there should be maximum transparency and community oversight It doesn t matter to me how things have always been done If elected Mayor of Parkville I will put you in the room I will be your voice And if the Board of Aldermen don t like that Tough I won t stand by and allow them to Kansas City our Parkville

great county as well as the challenges we face Many of the rest of you have known me through friendships made over the years around our community maybe we served together on a committee or our kids showed livestock together or you re part of my family or network of friends Regardless of how we became connected I sincerely appreciate your friendship and your support n nAs you are well aware I am seeking to be your next Wise County Precinct Commissioner and I want to say a huge thank you for supporting me in that endeavor Your support means more to me than I can possibly convey in this note n nAs we go forward I believe there are certain core values and passions that unite us not only for this campaign but for our future n nKnowing what s right and doing what s right matters n nIntegrity character and passion matter n nLeadership experience service those QUALIFICATIONS matter n nPREPARATION matters n nMost of you know my business experience entrepreneurial spirit and leadership record in community service organizations My past experience QUALIFIES me for this elected office n nWhat you might not know is what I ve done the past year to PREPARE specifically for my role as your next County Commissioner n nDuring the past months I have attended over county meetings from Commissioners Court workshops department meetings and budget meetings n nI have also met multiple times with our County Judge individual Commissioners county department heads and our County Sheriff with some of those meetings lasting multiple hours n nI ve taken hundreds of pages of notes studied the details of our county budget researched county issues and learned countless other useful information about the function of our county government n nThis is why I can say with confidence that I am THE MOST PREPARED candidate for commissioner n nI have conducted this campaign as I have run my business and civic organizations above reproach with the utmost respect for the rule of law ethics and organized detail and planning n nI have conducted this campaign with the purpose of educating constituents as to why one should vote FOR me rather than vote against my opponents Even in the face of blatantly false accusations and negative implications towards me I have remained positive and my campaign has remained positive That being said and in addition to the preparedness and qualifications I have stated above there are several other areas where I set myself apart from one or both of my opponents n n I am committed to be a FULL TIME COMMISSIONER The County Commissioner is a full time position I have planned and prepared to step away from the day to day responsibilities of my company and commit fully to the taxpayers and citizens of Precinct as I serve as their Commissioner n n I firmly believe I have the personal support of several prominent and key leaders of our county and within our own Precinct and will continue to work to earn that support The show of support from community members leaders and elected officials has been a great encouragement to me and my campaign n n I took time to educate myself on campaign election laws including sign placement Every one of my signs has been placed at a legal location where I have the permission of the property owner organization Thus far I have not had to relocate a single sign because of improper placement n n I have attended almost every Commissioners Court meeting over the past year n n I have attended EVERY candidate forum that was open to the candidates for Precinct Commissioner Even when I tested positive for Covid and felt poorly I made arrangements to participate remotely and discuss the issues and my passion for serving n n I have a great but not perfect voting record I have missed voting once in the last years n n I continue to be a proud Republican n nI hope you consider my words policy positions and values and I hope you agree that n nI am the most QUALIFIED candidate n nI am the most PREPARED candidate n nI am asking for you to Vote COLBY SHAWN FOR COMMISSIONER n nI will show up every day and will work tirelessly for you n nMay God bless the United States of America nMay God bless Texas and nMay God bless Wise County n nThank you nColby

For unsung heroes most of all AllUSHeroes Sheroes Life c Portraits Original Prints honor people s Diversity Dignity Equality and Standing Free in c nVideo is posted in recognition of current Month for Black History and Women s History Month upcoming in March n n c Timeline Capsule nEarly s Portrait Studies nWorks aimed to reflect c diverse population express the conviction that everyone has something to say thus worthy of a portrait nEarly s Editions XL nWorks came to symbolize All US Heroes in facing ongoing grave c challenges but now most of all Covid s to save oneself and the lives of others nMulti media works on varying archival paper media Affordable x s and x s n n covidnurse covid Heroessheroes AllUSHeroes Socialjustice n ERAnow EqualityNow sheroes onereasonwhyiamaglobalfeminist metoo globalfeminism womenshistorymonth MeTooMvmt contemporaryart NYCgallery IdeasMatter artmixedmedia artlover artcollector lgbtq asianamerican latina gaymarriage immigrationreform
A lot of GOP politicians and political pundits are blaming Biden for this inflation THEY ARE LYING TO YOU n n If Biden s spending is causing this inflation why didn t we see inflation rise in when Trump spent EVEN MORE money n n Why did inflation not spike back in March when Biden s only stimulus went out n n Why did inflation rise AFTER the Federal Unemployment benefit was eliminated completely in September And it was already reduced from per week when Trump was president down to per week when Biden took office n n How could Biden s spending with his Infrastructure Bill cause inflation BEFORE any money from it was spent n n Why would inflation rise after Biden REDUCED THE DEFICIT and spent LESS money than Trump n nThe TRUTH is that Biden s spending is NOT THE CAUSE OF THIS INFLATION n nSo what is causing this inflation n nThere are several factors that are causing today s inflation n n When the pandemic hit in we went into lock down Restaurants closed People stopped spending money Demand dropped Manufacturers drastically slowed or even stopped manufacturing part in response to the reduced demand and part in response to the lack of labor due to the people getting Covid and or being quarantined n n When the lock downs ended and people started going back out earlier this year they not only went back to spending money they made up for lost time This created a huge and sudden increase in demand n n Unfortunately increasing supplies is not that simple Our supplier chain is made up of millions of products from all around the globe and many of our larger more complex items have to be manufactured from other parts in the global chain and these manufacturers can t up their output until their suppliers up theirs It s not just the manufacturers that have to ramp back up it s shipping companies trucking companies retailers and everybody in between n n Inflation increases the costs of doing business which in a free market should cause a reduction in corporate profits Yet many large companies showed RECORD PROFITS this year This is because in several large industries there are only a handful of competitors which allows them to raise prices above what a free market would allow and they have used the pandemic and supply chain issues as an excuse to do exactly that n nThe bottom line is that Demand was able to increase much faster than supply THAT along with the corporate manipulation of prices IS WHAT IS DRIVING THIS INFLATION n nP S Let s remember that the President does not control inflation Our economy is based on a free market Absent extreme circumstances he cannot order companies to raise or lower prices or to keep them the same He certainly cannot dictate to foreign companies what they can charge n n

According to renowned political economist Raj Patel rajpateluk and physician and activist Rupa Marya rupa marya our bodies our societies and our planet are inflamed From the Covid pandemic and the shocking racial disparities in its impact to the international response to systemic racism and the backlash from it as well as climate change and the refugees that result from the changes to our planet our bodies are responding to it all through various forms of inflammation n nInflammation is deeply connected to everything the food we eat the air we breathe and the diversity of the microbes living inside us regulating everything from our brain s development to our immune system s functioning It is connected to the traumatic events we experienced as children as well as the traumas endured by our ancestors It can also be the result of access or lack thereof to healthcare and the very models of healthcare that physicians practice n nIn their recent book Inflamed Raj and Rupa reveal the links between health and structural injustices and offer a new deep medicine that can heal our bodies and our world n nJoin Raj and Rupa for a rich unique conversation with professor Charlotte Mar a S enz as they illuminate the hidden relationships between our biological systems and the profound injustices of our political and economic systems Explore the deep medicine of decolonization and its potential to heal not just our bodies but the world n nRegister for this free live online conversation at the linktree in our bio n n deepmedicine inflamed decolonization inflamedbook rajpatel rupamarya ciissf ciissffaculty ciispublicprograms ciispubprograms conversation medicine health healthcare caretakers injustice unjusthealthcare
Caleb Hafler has lived in Chemung County all his life and grew up in Pine City He moved to the th District five years ago when he married his wife Alivia He has two children and attends Grace Lee Memorial Church in Beaver Dams New York He is a Conservative Republican nCaleb is an expert in his trade Straight out of high school Caleb was hired by Newcomer Remodeling There he excelled and perfected his skill in the trade of carpentry He now owns his own construction business Hafler Home Improvement HHI has grown to be a well respected and quality construction business in Chemung County nThrough his business Caleb spends a great deal of time with his fellow community members improving their homes He has gotten to know many people families throughout Chemung County He hopes to be able to serve the people on a more personal level and continue to get to know and meet the needs of the people who live here nCaleb is a passionate person and has a real vision for not only Chemung County but more specifically District As a father in this community Caleb sees the importance of standing for strong family values He seeks to help make his district a place where families can flourish and grow If elected Caleb plans to take real and practical steps towards making his community a place where people want to stay and raise their families Caleb states Elmira is a beautiful place to live filled with rich history and wonderful people I want to restore a sense of pride in our community nCaleb is a big supporter of small businesses With all the recent restrictions and attacks on our local businesses as of late Caleb sees the need to aid business owners in building back their livelihoods Caleb realizes that good local businesses are the backbone of any community He would like to help them get to the point of thriving not just surviving As well as protect and stand up for their constitutional rights nCaleb has many plans to better our community Right now we are all facing perhaps the biggest threat to our freedoms most of us have ever seen in our lifetime Caleb states The infringement on our basic constitutional rights through the Covid mask Vaccine mandates come from Albany but make their way down here to us in Chemung County Caleb wants to be very clear that if elected he will be voting against these mandates He strongly believes in the freedoms we have in this great country and aims to uphold them for the people of Chemung County and District nCaleb is stepping up for his community He hopes to make a difference and is willing to work hard Caleb wants to better his community for his children and yours He s not going anywhere he s staying here n nHere to listen Here to serve Here to stay n nTo stay up to date on Caleb Hafler s campaign please visit his Facebook page n n

There is no such a thing as finished reform That s one of the reasons why high income countries continuously reform their healthcare systems The countries are in globalized word connected and they tend to inspire each other and similar reforms are often introduced across countries However politicians are keen to get inspired by other countries in a limited way Recent paper offers overview of health reform trends in high income countries before the covid pandemic n n Even before the pandemic countries were facing challenges which persist today The most important challenges are gaps coverage and access concerns about quality integration and continuity of care workforce shortages the epidemiological shift to multiple chronic diseases emerging viral threats as well as other unpredictable exogenous shocks These are the challenges which lie ahead of us and the competent will be forced to willy nilly to deal with it The question is how they are going to do it n n The average age of the population in most developed countries is growing which means that the demand for healthcare will exponentially grow as well The demand in future will concentrate on person centred care n n In the paper were reviewed reforms which were reported in countries in of them went to four clusters insurance cover age resource generation governance healthcare purchasing payment and organization of hospitalcare n n In reforms in countries were reported of them fell under organization of primary ambulatory care governance care coordination specialized care and organization of hospital care n n Most reforms were reported ongoing in implemented seven abandoned Health agency ledreforms were implemented most frequently followed by central government legislated reforms n n Policymakers can leverage international experience of distinct reform approaches addressing similar challenges and similar approaches to address distinct problems Such knowledge may help inspireor support future successful health reform processes

T oo many families are struggling to keep up with their bills Inflation is robbing them of the gains they thought otherwise they would be able to feel I get it That was President Joe Biden in his first State of the Union Address on March attempting at least to deflect some of the blame for inflation away from the federal government s unprecedented peacetime spending borrowing and printing avalanche of more than trillion in response to the Covid pandemic That included the trillion CARES Act and billion phase four legislation under former President Donald Trump and the trillion stimulus and billion of new infrastructure spending under President Biden As a result the national debt has increased by trillion to trillion of which the Fed monetized half or trillion by increasing its share of U S treasuries to a record trillion Overall the M money supply has increased by trillion to trillion a whopping percent increase Almost every new dollar of debt was paid for by printing it What more is needed to explain the current bout of inflation Biden doesn t get it This State of the Union was an opportunity to level with the American people If Biden had explained the situation honestly and promised to slow down spending and increase American energy production it could have been an historic pivot that might have saved his Congressional majorities in November Biden is right when says inflation is robbing the American people blind And in they re going to have something to say about it What do you think

Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell announced March the Fed will begin hiking interest rates this month with inflation running hot at percent the past twelve months after the federal government spent borrowed and printed more than trillion to combat Covid Being so close to the Covid recession the Federal Reserve has left interest rates at near zero percent throughout the duration of the recovery Meaning if a recession were to happen now the central bank would not be able to assist the economy by moving interest rates any lower But did the Fed wait too long

Sustainability n nAs members of a Select Board all decisions about limited resources should be measured against the goal of sustainability n nWe are in a unique position in history with extra funds because of Federal Covid Aid we must ensure we are not increasing budgets in town based on a false sense of financial security We must look at ways to supplement the budget for one time expense and capital projects and go after grants with gusto There is money to be had through grants and partnering with other local leaders These are dollars and services the people of Lakeville could benefit from and making it a priority will be a priority to me n nIt s imperative the role of Select Board member is seen as a role of stewardship Lakeville has fantastic people scenic nature and a central location When we add all those things together we become an attractive place to develop Not to say all development is bad for Lakeville but we must ensure we can balance the needs to increase our business and industry tax base and not increase tax burden on homeowners with the need to preserve all that makes Lakeville the town we love n nThe April th Election is around the corner and I would be honored to represent what I believe in and the people of Lakeville if I am elected to serve n nThank you nMaureen Candito
With women s rights under attack and new movements emerging in which women are leading the fightback it is more vital than ever to understand the roots of women s oppression and why a revolutionary struggle for socialism is the only solution to it n nStarting with a summary of what happened to women when Covid arrived in Britain the pamphlet moves on to consider the global context It describes the rise of authoritarian regimes around the world which have gathered strength under the impact of the crisis of capitalism environmental destruction and inter imperialist rivalry all of which have combined to worsen the conditions of all women and in particular black Asian and other minority ethnic women n nAn inclusive summary of socialist movements for women internationally and in Britain takes the reader through the history and the pamphlet considers the demands and programmes of women in the past and today The key question throughout each chapter is a close examination from different perspectives of the role of the family in the oppression of women and indeed the entire working class under capitalism n nJoin us for talks and discussion on International Women s Day n nTuesday March pm nThe Flying Duck n Renfield Street nGlasgow nG AU n nPamphlets will be available to buy on the night and are also available to buy online here by n nGlasgow Fight Racism Fight Imperialism Revolutionary Communist Group n nFollow or contact us nInsta Facebook Glasgow FRFI nEmail glasgowfrfi gmail com nPhone
Alan Lowe for Palm Coast City Council District n nHere are some bullet points items of my platform followed by a little more detail n n I oppose tax increases n n I support a fiscally responsible government n n I oppose uncontrolled development n n I support development that does not affect adjacent land values n n I oppose zoning changes that will harm adjacent property values n n I support a healthy business atmosphere n n I support government transparency n n I support ensuring there is a quality and detailed cost benefit analysis performed on all significant projects n n I support public town halls at various locations around town to promote public interaction and comment n n I support a third party forensic budget review to identify areas of wasteful spending n nAs your city councilman I will be a public servant and a community leader that actually listens n nNot only will I bring the expected integrity and transparency back to City Hall I will also bring the truth that all city employees whether elected appointed or hired are servants of the people and that the citizens of Palm Coast deserve their respect in all interactions n nI will fight to restore trust City Council of Palm Coast and make your interests my first priority n nI believe in small government and see the government s role as representing the needs of the people and not controlling the public access to information n nI want to serve our city in the best interest of our citizens and lead others by example n nI don t want to play the role of protector but rather one of a civic partner that listens and understands that we need to build an environment of prosperity that attracts people to our city from all walks of life all age groups and instills a sense of pride in living in a community that is willing to evolve to be so much more n nI believe in transparency and creating community interactions by bringing the voice of the people to city hall n nI do believe monthly in person town hall meetings are essential and necessary to keep in close touch with the public to be accessible transparent and present n nI believe that business investments that will create lasting well paid jobs are an essential basis for our city and I am concerned that several important businesses left the city during the past years We need to work on bringing good companies to our city by creating an inviting atmosphere to entice new businesses to call Palm Coast Home I would call for the creation of a committee of local business owners to identify city road blocks to a successful business atmosphere and excessive red tape and then belp devise plans to eliminate them n nWe are all facing economical challenges now more than ever following the Covid lock downs uncontrolled inflation and an uncertain economy and so is the city However I do not believe in raising taxes as the only method to create revenue to fill the city s coffers Instead I believe in creating a thriving business environment to attract investments into our city Tax revenue generated from businesses should help alleviate the pressure of tax dollars gleaned from private residential property tax As such improving the business atmosphere will bring more businesses from which the city can improve the tax base and reduce the burden on the individual n nOUR SHERIFF PARAMEDICS AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS n nSheriff nI support our county Sheriff and his deputies I believe in the work they are doing and their efforts to stem crime and remove drugs from our streets They risk their lives to bring people to justice only to have the courts let them go I have personally witnessed the Sheriff s office close a neighboring drug house and bring the perpetrators to justice n n nParamedics nI have great respect for our paramedics and fire fighting force My mother was very ill and I brought her to our home to take care of her until the end I had to call the paramedics to our home on several occasions They were always prompt courteous and gentile with her As we have an aging community the paramedics are life savers n n nFirefighters nI was here for the fires in the early s and spent a few hours out in the middle of the Pine Lakes golf course to escape the fire Then in I lost my house to the raging forest fires The firefighters did all they could to save as many homes as possible and they fought hard I use to enjoy seeing the events and comments on their Facebook page and will push to get them back online so as to help them be engaged with the community and have a direct link to present information and advertise events n n nMENTAL HEALTH nFlagler County has the dubious honor of having one of if not the highest suicide rates in Florida I experienced this first hand when my father who was diagnosed with dementia took his own life n nAlthough there was no outward sign that he was in trouble he obviously was After he passed friends and family comforted my mom for several days but she we was were then left to our own I believe there should be a city supported outreach program in Palm Coast that reaches out to families affected by these tragedies Even if it is a just a phone call with a friendly voice saying hello how is your day going n nTAXES n I have skin in the game By this I mean that I own property pay property taxes and am keenly aware of the burden increased taxes place upon the community I understand that the government is an entity that survives off of the fruits of other people s labor I will work hard to keep your taxes low and tirelessly look for areas to cut spending eliminate waste and make departments accountable I won t play games pretending a flattened milage rate is a reduction in your property taxes When property values go up the amount paid in property tax with a flat or minimally reduced milage rate still goes up Many of our residents are Senior Citizens who fled the tax drain of other states for the sunshine low taxes and a better life on their fixed incomes We have a responsibility to see to it that Seniors enjoy their retirement without the fear of high taxes and our younger generations have a chance to start without the burden of high taxation holding them back All citizens of Palm Coast deserve a responsible city government n n nA FISCALLY RESPONSIBLE GOVERNMENT nWhen your bank account gets low you tighten your belt cut out nonessential spending and revise your budget Shouldn t we expect our government to do the same thing It is beneficial for our city to receive grants from the outside but we should not be relying on outside help to soften the impact of bloated spending habits If there is waste then lets find it If there is a better way to achieve the same goals but costs less then lets do it Although we have audits that show the city is on track there are always ways to improve As we enter a time of potential reduced revenue generation for the city we should be reviewing our capital improvements with an eye for delaying or tabling projects that may not be immediately essential

Post of As promised here is the second installment from the Belleville PBA Official Endorsement Including the actual letter from the Belleville PBA and related media coverage of this historic endorsement n nThey have my back today and WILL have my back in the upcoming May election for Mayor Period n nWhy Because I ve had their back from July and whether or not I received this rare endorsement if I m blessed to serve another term as Mayor my commitment to them and to law and order would have remained steadfast n nI have not only praised them at times when it wasn t popular to do so but I also spoke out for and defended our BPD when they couldn t always do so themselves n nWhile I m proud and honored by their support I know my Father is smiling as he looks down on both me and our Belleville PD As a child I learned what public service was by watching my mom and dad My father always loved our PD and was one of the volunteers who assisted in raising money for the department s first bullet proof vests Today the plague he received from the then Commissioner is prominently displayed in the Mayor s Office n nNext I expect a letter going out from the State PBA to the hundreds of active and retired PBA Members currently living in Belleville to make them formally aware of the endorsement and strongly recommend their support n n n nIn a rare move the local police union is making an endorsement for mayor throwing its support behind Mayor Michael Melham for four more years of service n nThe endorsement posted to the Belleville PBA s official social media channels read Belleville PBA Local is proud to announce our support for Incumbent Mayor Michael Melham in his re election campaign for Mayor of the Township of Belleville Mayor Melham has time and time again shown his support for law enforcement and first responders through the Covid Pandemic as well as the sweeping anti police movement He has shown his support by standing with Local and our community n nMelham is running for re election on Tuesday May with his slate of candidates Deputy Mayor Naomy DePe a and Councilman at large Tommy Graziano n nIn receiving the endorsement Melham said he was extremely humbled and absolutely thrilled to have the support and official endorsement of the men and women of our fine Belleville Police Department n nThe endorsement is noteworthy because the Belleville PBA has not endorsed a candidate for local office in decades n n That s why Local voluntarily stepping out with its official endorsement means so much especially during these trying times Melham said This was not solicited rather it happened organically with the men and women of Local knowing I ve had their back unconditionally for years In return they wanted to show me that they have my back in this upcoming May municipal election n nThe mayor added We seem to live in a world that s upside down Good is bad and bad is somehow good These hard working men and women put their lives on the line every single day for us Sadly it has recently become all too popular to make them scapegoats often by elected officials Bureaucrats have been no better creating legislation after legislating neutering law enforcement and perpetuating a culture of disrespect This sickens to me n nMelham expressed his appreciation to Police Chief Mark Minichini as well as the PBA including PBA President John Hood and PBA Vice President State Delegate Steven Plumer n n I sincerely thank you for your strong show of support and commitment to my re election and to our collective vision of creating a BetterBelleville for all Belleville residents Melham said Stay safe and stay strong

New Episode Local Really Matters In this episode we discuss the sudden disappearance of the Covid masks and vaccine mandates What happened Did the science change Did we finally get rid of it as guaranteed on inauguration day We also discuss the crime rate that is plaguing NYC How did we get here Can it be changed What can we do if anything Plus Americans are mad NYC podcast politics gasprices mandates
Join us for this online discussion as part of The Open University s events for British Science Week n nFollow The Open University on Twitter and Facebook for updates on all of or BSW events nThe public understanding of genetics is fraught with oversimplifications and misconceptions This gives fertile ground for abuse by White supremacists who claim superiority via some pure ancestry or by eugenicists who assign inferiority to certain people e g with dark skin The rise of consumer level genetic tests fanned this further Both test sellers and consumers misleadingly talk about having the gene for musical ability or screening the embryo for top intelligence In this talk I will refer to my research to explain how so much of it is wishful misunderstanding and how the science is so nuanced nGet to know our expert nDr Kaustubh Adhikari is a lecturer in Statistics at The Open University He carries out research on the application of statistics to genetics after obtaining a PhD from Harvard University He has appeared on the BBC to talk about his research and on the use of statistics He does many public engagement events on the use and misuse of statistics for example about Covid
The British family farm could die out in the next years Provided British agriculture stays on the path it s on that may well be the direction we are heading According to data from Defra farms of less than hectares have halved in number in the last years Small holdings have also seen a dramatic decrease too from around in to less than in n nSmall scale family farms are facing an uncertain future putting the future of the sector at risk With increasing concerns over trade deals and the new agricultural bill looming it s an increasingly worrying time for small producers many of whom have shown incredible courage and resilience keeping the country fed through the outbreak of Covid earlier this year n nWhy are Small Scale British Farms Disappearing n nThe number of US style mega farms in the UK has increased by in the past years alone This collapse in family farms has in part been driven by the rise of concentrated animal feeding operations CAFOs In these industrial farming units pigs cows and chickens are crammed by the thousand into rows of barns Many units are semi automated with feeding run by computer with periodic visits by workers n nIndustrial farming dominates animal production and has an outsized influence on crop growing and land usage The UK is now home to at least mega farms classed as CAFOs Most highly geared industrial farms are not far off the CAFO status and there are thousands of industrial farms taking up huge swathes of British land once home to a tapestry of smaller farms n nHow Can we Create a Food System that Supports Small Scale Farms n nThere is extensive evidence of the important role that small scale farms have in our agricultural landscape creating jobs supporting rural communities and reducing inputs and waste on mixed farms n nSmall farms such as these are often written off as inefficient or low output But a study carried out by the Prince s Countryside Fund points out top performing small family farms are just as efficient as many of the country s much larger ones Especially when it comes to producing higher quality food grass fed hand reared free range self sustaining and regenerating n nSecuring a Future for Small Scale Farmers n nWe work directly with around small scale British family farms all who rear native breed meat in harmony with nature Excitingly we are also growing our range to include hundreds of products from many more small scale artisan producers around the country from small scale artisan cheesemakers to family run flour mills growing and milling heritage grains and many many more n nFor us true sustainability also includes building sustainable communities ensuring everyone in the chain is receiving a fair price and that the true cost of our food is being accounted for We aim to enable small family farms to thrive by building strong relationships direct with our customers n nBy shopping with Pipers Farm your money is going back into the community It is helping us to ensure we are able to farm in a way that tackles the climate crisis regenerating rather than depleting our soils It is funding projects such as laying down new hedgerows planting trees improving water cycles and converting to renewable energy It s allowing traditional artisan skills to thrive in rural communities providing important links such as low throughput abattoirs and local feed mills Importantly your support is securing a future for small scale British family farms n nDiscover more at
Do you need one of your Covid vaccines Are you unsure about getting it and want to ask questions n nHead to n Churchill Square Shopping Centre n am pm n Everyday n n st nd booster No appointment needed n n More info

Connectivity is a Human Right n n Those who are not connected are living in a very different world even more so during the pandemic and these disparities are among the starkest in refugee communities Executive Director and CEO of USA for UNHCR Anne Marie Grey n nWe all have a human right to be a part of a connected society Still the coronavirus pandemic has made it difficult for refugee communities to access technologies further isolating them from connecting with family members accessing information and finding protection resources
In case you ve missed this n nFood Deserts Scarcity in the Land of Plenty nThe phrase food desert may sound like something from a dystopian science fiction movie but living in a food desert is a reality that a surprising number of Americans face every day The term was first coined by the Scottish Nutrition Task Force in and first introduced to the US via the Farm Bill Food Conservation and Energy Act of n nFood deserts are areas that lack access to affordable fresh meats dairy products fruits vegetables whole grains and other foods that make up a healthy diet they are a major factor in overall food insecurity in our nation The USDA defines a food desert as having a poverty rate of or greater and by how close residents are to supermarkets In urban food deserts people live more than a mile away from a supermarket In rural food deserts distance to a grocery store is greater than miles nA USDA report showed that the main characteristics of food desert areas are a very large or very sparse population low income high levels of unemployment inadequate access to transportation and a low number of food retailers providing fresh produce at affordable prices n nFood desert residents usually struggle with a combination of these factors and there are differing schools of thought regarding food deserts and their true effects n nAvailability Accessibility and Affordability Are Issues Or Are They nThe most wide spread thinking holds that residents of food deserts have difficulty juggling availability accessibility and affordability of healthy food to the extent that their health suffers Without ready access to full service supermarkets it can also be difficult for those with dietary restrictions to find appropriate food to fit their cultural or health needs n nEven in cases where healthy food is readily available the cost can be a major barrier for consumers In a comprehensive study was done that compiled data from studies in countries It showed that the cost of healthy food is about more per day than less healthy options which makes for per person per year The total increase for a family of four is over which can be a substantial amount for low income households n nIn the USDA found that million households both lived in a food desert and lacked access to a vehicle Thus the thinking goes even if those people can afford to buy healthy foods it can be difficult for them to get to a grocery store and they may therefore rely more heavily on fast food restaurants and convenience stores n nA paradox exists in urban food deserts amidst a scarcity of healthy food there is a high percentage of obese people due to the increased consumption of less healthy foods The result is a prevalence of obesity and other diet related health conditions such as diabetes and heart disease in those areas A study of Chicago neighborhoods found that deaths from diabetes in food deserts were actually double those in areas with relatively easy access to grocery stores n nConversely a study by the Journal of the American Heart Association JAHA found that association between food deserts and adverse outcomes is largely driven by low area income not poor access to food n nFurther research from New York University NYU showed between and more than a thousand supermarkets opened nationwide in neighborhoods around the country that had previously been food deserts NYU studied the grocery purchases of about households in those neighborhoods While it s true that these households buy less healthy groceries than people in wealthier neighborhoods they do not start buying healthier groceries after a new supermarket opened Instead we find that people shop at the new supermarket but they buy the same kinds of groceries they had been buying before n nIn addition the study also stated the average American travels miles to shop and percent of shopping trips are made by car In fact low income households are not much different they travel an average of miles Since we re traveling that far we tend to shop in supermarkets even if there isn t one down the street Even people who live in zip codes with no supermarkets still buy percent of their groceries from supermarkets n nConsidering that there are countless educational resources for people who wish to learn how to make good dietary choices it would seem that the biggest factor in individual health simply boils down to personal choice This is not to belittle the effects of insufficient nutrition which tends to have the heaviest effect on children in low income areas n nLong Term Effects Go Far Beyond Nutrition nNutrition or the lack thereof affects more than physical health Studies have shown that children who struggle with poor nutrition are more likely to have social and behavioral problems in school This can lead to students dropping out of school and other types of failed education which very often result in economic failures later in life n nThe long term economic cycle in areas deemed to be food deserts are vicious Multi generational families in food deserts tend to experience decreasing wealth which leads to businesses leaving the area which means fewer employment opportunities which leads to even further reduced wealth When new stores open they open in areas of higher income to reduce the risk of their investment The decreased buying power of customers in low income areas and the threat of higher crime rates whether real or perceived tend to push businesses away Some go so far as to label the results food apartheid since food insecurity affects minority groups to a greater degree n nFood Insecurity Most Prevalent in Southern States nIt follows then that the highest concentration of food insecure communities are located in areas with higher populations of minority groups n nThe USDA has calculated that there are total census tracts in the United States which fall within the parameters to be considered a food desert The USDA website states a census tract is a small relatively permanent subdivision of a county that usually contains between and people but generally averages around people Rural counties make up of total counties in the country but they make up of counties with the highest rates of food insecurity n nA December USDA survey showed that of total US households were food insecure with being at low food security status and at very low food security status These percentages account for million people including million children Of those children live in households that experience very low food security n nThis particular survey defined low food insecure households as being able to obtain enough food to mostly maintain their eating patterns or to reduce food intake by eating less varied diets This group was also able to rely on assistance from federal programs and local food pantries n nVery low food security status was defined by having the normal eating patterns of one or more household members disrupted by food scarcity and by cases of overall food intake being reduced due to lack of money and other resources to obtain food n nNo Easy Answers nConsidering the differing schools of thought on the issue is not clear how geographic location truly affects food insecurity or what measures to alleviate it are most effective n nOhio University writes Dealing with food deserts across the United States is a complex issue with no easy solutions It is difficult for communities and cities to simply build more grocery stores develop more transit options or find ways to help individuals generate more income to purchase healthy foods nConversely New York University stated Over the past decade federal and local governments in the United States have spent hundreds of millions of dollars encouraging grocery stores to open in food deserts The federal Healthy Food Financing Initiative has leveraged over billion in financing for grocers in under served areas Meanwhile cities such as Houston and Denver have sought to institute related measures at the local level n nSome mistakenly believe that subsidies for commodities like corn and soy work to lower the prices of foods that are more processed and less healthy Some blame the market driven polices that focus on turning out inexpensive high volume highly processed food products for maximum industry profit One school of thought holds that placing a sin tax on less healthy foods would discourage their purchase n nWhile a variety of programs exist to help with food insecurity they can only do so much especially considering that inflation supply chain issues and food shortages are currently impacting all Americans In fact researchers at Northwestern University found that food insecurity more than doubled because of the covid pandemic affecting up to of households Of course the already precarious situation of millions of food insecure people has been greatly exacerbated by the current state of affairs in our nation n nThrough the tangled web of issues surrounding food insecurity one thing is abundantly clear our nation s food producers are more important than ever

in Londoners is anxious about returning to work How can employers and HR help n nInevitably the lack of government mandated isolation along with the reduced testing availability will cause disruptions in the workplace n nEmployers might struggle to convince employees to return to work due to safety concerns which subsequently will give rise to ethical concerns n nIf employees are asked to return to work how can employers take responsibility and show they care about health and safety Should they take initiative and implement testing measures among staff n nThere is a number of measures employers can implement to ensure that their workplace is Covid secure such as adapting workstations with social distancing and sanitation facilities in mind and provide hybrid or fully remote options to workers who are vulnerable immunosuppressed or pregnant But above all the fact of the matter is there is no substitute for regular testing which is the only way employers can reliably protect their workforce and provide stability to their business n nIt could even be argued that now that the government decided to reduce testing measures employers should be proud to be able to provide free testing to their staff n nIn light of this PeploBio has been working hard to provide workplace testing nationwide n nIf you re an employer click n learn more to see our testing plans or visit our website n n n n humanresources businessleaders hrtips management publichealth labourlaw anxiety workplacewellness london covidtesting covidtestingsites healthservices companyperks employeeperks

As you may have heard there has developed a concern as to whether I live in Live Oak County Texas The short of it is that I have lived on FM Three Rivers Live Oak County Texas for over years This address has been on my driver s license voter s registration truck registration insurance income tax all billing addresses etc since nThe long of my moving back to this address is personal but if it helps dispel this false accusation I will be happy to share Though I had lived in Live Oak County since I was months old my parents bought this place after my freshman year of high school and I lived at this address until leaving for college in After years of college I got married and over the next years lived first in the Houston area then in Floresville before getting divorced and moving to the family ranch in Three Rivers nMy mother having passed away over years ago spent the last years of her life confined to a wheelchair and on twice daily home kidney dialysis If you are not familiar with the process it is not a pleasant experience In addition to being connected to tubes for most of the day your home is transformed into a make shift hospital room and your living and dining rooms turned into storage for an unimaginable quantity of fluid boxes This is quite the burden on anyone and feeling compelled to not allow my father to shoulder that burden alone I moved back to their house nDuring the last years I spent years earning a Master s degree in Business Administration attending evening classes at the University of Texas at San Antonio I later earned a Doctorate in law being part of the inaugural class of the Evening Program for St Mary s University School of Law This whole time working full time and commuting from Three Rivers nI opened my law firm in the center of Three Rivers a decade ago Eventually I purchased the building from Michael Dubose Jeannie Snider still holds her Dance by Jeannie classes in the studio in the back of the building This can be confirmed through a search of Live Oak County Deed records and or the Tax records of the Appraisal District Twelve hour days are quite common here so a minute commute has been a blessing nIn I married Lori who has spent her career in civil service at Randolph Air Force Base and has less than years remaining until retirement Her primary residence since our marriage has been Three Rivers which can be confirmed as the address on her driver s license This has been possible since the Covid pandemic forced her agency to telework entirely from home for over a year Her office continues to telework days a week nIf you would like to visit with me in person please feel free to stop by my office at Bluhm Law Firm located at West Thornton Street Three Rivers Live Oak County Texas

Since July the Tunisian government has implemented mass vaccination campaigns with well over five million people vaccinated so far A key element that has played a role in the success of the vaccination campaign is cold chain infrastructure nUNICEF and its partners took action to protect children and their caretakers by building up cold chain infrastructure to safely transport and store vaccines in Tunisia nUNICEF with a donation from the Government of Japan bought equipment that was handed over to the Ministry of Health between February and July a critical element to start the vaccination of the frontline workers The equipment included refrigerators and freezers all at the Performance Quality and Safety PQS World Health Organization standards and vaccine temperature recorders an essential requirement for the safe storage of Covid vaccines nUSAID is another major funder of cold chain infrastructure development in the fight against Covid in Tunisia Through USAID the U S was able to support the upgrading of equipment to meet global standards including the installment of remote temperature monitoring sensors that are required for safe storage Since the beginning of the pandemic the U S has provided Tunisia with over million in assistance in addition to over million life saving vaccines as a demonstration of our continued commitment to ending this global pandemic nRead more de la sant nJapan The Government of Japan nAmbassade du Japon en Tunisie nUSAID Middle East nU S Embassy Tunis

Friends nWe are down to the last few days of the legislative session when we are primarily considering Senate Legislation We will finish the session next Monday April th n nSupporting Healthcare n nThe House unanimously passed Senate Bills and SB updates medical education accrediting provisions to ensure that Georgia is able to continue to train top caliber doctors SB requires that insurers authorize medications for chronic conditions for a minimum of one year Currently in some cases insurers require frequent reauthorization by a Georgian doctor of long term prescriptions for chronic conditions This legislation would streamline and simplify that process for patients nMilitary Men and Women to Enter Law Enforcement nSenate Bill which unanimously passed the House repays some of the costs incurred by active duty retired or honorable discharged military men and women who attend law enforcement training Costs are limited to tuition costs that are not covered by other available resources Georgia is home to one of the largest military populations in the country These men and women have served our country honorably many of them leave the military and continue to have an interest in serving their communities while having backgrounds that can transfer easily to law enforcement with additional training n nChildren in District nThe House passed Senate Bill which creates an open and transparent complaint process for parents who are concerned about harmful content in our schools n nWhile a complaint process is required now unfortunately the lack of any deadlines or required transparency means that some schools and school systems may choose to make the process more difficult than it needs to be or delay a response hoping that a complainant goes away nThis legislation simply requires that complaints be investigated in days with a parent meeting occurring within days Should a parent wish to appeal to the local school board that appeal must be heard within days nThe ultimate decision in these cases remains with schools we are simply giving parents confidence in the process n nThe House also passed Senate Bill the Unmask Georgia Students Act While most Georgia school systems have eliminated mask mandates they remain in place even today in some schools Seeing these mandates linger long past any significant perceived threat to students or teachers from Covid highlights the importance of this legislation n nSenate Bill provides that no public school board of education or school leadership can make or enforce a mask mandate without providing an opt out for parents Parents cannot be required to provide a reason and their children cannot be subject to adverse consequences for doing so n nOn a more somber note there is unfortunately evil in this world That s one of the reasons the House had to pass Senate Bill This legislation affirms that a parent found guilty of homicide in the death of his or her child cannot recover any money or property as a result of that child s death Following an emotional speech from the General Assembly s longest serving member Representative Calvin Smyre the House passed SB by a See Sherriff Jason Mikesell s Endorsement here the City of Woodland Park Voters nI have had the pleasure of working with Hilary for many years and was happy she stepped forward into the role of Mayor for city of Woodland Park I first meet Hillary at the Republican meetings and quickly saws that she was a very strong supporter of our constitution I also was a supporter of her platform in running for the mayor position As follows were the platforms she chose nDecision Making and Conduct n I will abide by our Federal and State Constitution n I will abide by our City Charter n I will abide by our Council policy and procedures which I co authored and introduced into Council during my year term There were no Council policies or procedures prior to my election as a council member n I have a strong voting record for protecting citizens property rights and limiting the overreach or growth of government n I would like to see our debt well controlled in order to bring forth meaningful tax reductions to our citizens n I do not believe that personal ideology belongs on the Dais n City Council is a non partisan position Potholes are not Democratic or Republican They just need to be fixed n I know the difference between the legal status of each agenda item There are Legislative Quasi Judicial and Administrative Knowing the difference helps to be prepared for meetings and how to properly discuss and vote for each item n Properly understanding the agenda allows for shorter more professional meetings no I will come prepared no I will act civilly no I will be mindful of time no I will not soap box my ideologies no I will be respectful of others disagreement can occur without disrespect no I will act with honor no I will value each and every public comment no I will strive to do everything in the public domain and during hearings no I will work to attract jobs business and tourism to our city no I will happily attend events and functions where I will positively and professionally represent our beautiful community nSupport small businesses n She will collaborate with Teller County and Council members to write a letter to the State asking for a waiver and requesting to re open our businesses during Covid lockdowns the County and City were granted the waiver n Encourage volunteering to our many boards who also help support our small businesses n I will properly vet board members and hold board members accountable for proper conduct n I supported the reduction of business license fees and will continue to support fiscal financial decisions that would support our small businesses and city n I am on record during the pandemic suggesting to make Woodland Park a sanctuary city for businesses so that they could not be shut down via larger government control during the pandemic nSupport our Law Enforcement n The safety of our citizens in the primary role of government n I will direct and foster cooperation with other enforcement agencies in Teller County looking for efficiencies and effectiveness and insist on measurable outcomes all focused on increased safety and security of our residents n I approved a fiscal budget which allowed for a raise for our invaluable Police Department n I support our First Responders and their programs n I will diligently pursue a positive and supportive working relationship with our City Manager and Staff n I will respect the professional feedback that I receive from the City Manager n I will respect the legal relationship that Council has as the employer of the City Manager n I will make sure that Council is providing clear and timely policy direction to our City Manager n I will take my role and Council s role seriously in providing professional useful performance evaluations to the City Manager n I will work through the City Manager to obtain action by Staff n I will Respect the staff for faithfully carrying out the will of the Council whether or not I share the view of the council majority nFoster a great relationship with Teller County Government and State Agencies n I worked jointly with Teller County Office of Emergency Management during and currently because of the Covid Pandemic n I will work with our county and our first responders to make sure our citizens are safe from disasters The recent fire in Boulder underscored we are all in this together n I will closely collaborate with Teller County and CDOT to consider a potential bypass for highway I have already signed an official request from the city to our commissioners to share in the cost of a bi pass analysis to be conducted by CDOT n I will support what our citizens envision for the future of Woodland Park n I believe in comprehensive and responsible planning for Land Use and growth orderly development is essential to our natural and fiscal resources and services the city provides n I will support zoning regulations subdivision regulations and a Master Plan that ensures the responsible growth of our community n I will continue to ensure the water tap management plan is implemented n I will use the comprehensive plan map to help determine proposed changes to city zoning n I will Respect and consider property rights of all impacted parties in my new term Short Term rentals will be on the agenda to be addressed by the community and council n I will thoroughly research the short term rental topic to know what success if any other cities have found when regulating the issue I believe strong consistent HOA s are the best place to start versus government intervention n I will maintain the overall character of Woodland Park n I will support the development of attainable affordable housing where feasible by supporting the development of for sale housing that is unsubsidized that meets the needs of those with incomes between and of the area s median income n I will support mixed use buildings in the downtown corridor n I will support Accessory Dwelling Units which allow seniors to age in place if their children family members or friends want to reside in the already owned larger residence n I will work with Teller County to update the Housing Needs Assessment n I will encourage citizen involvement in neighborhood planning n I am readily available to the citizens via phone email or in person meetings nThese are excerpts from her letter how many other candidates would take the time to identify all these needs as what they will do I am proud of Hillary for her thoughtfulness to the duties that are needed for the position of Mayor nI am proud to endorse Hilary LaBarre for Mayor of Woodland Park nSincerely nJason Mikesell

The Calhoun County Journal has partnered with the City of Oxford to host candidate forums The forums will allow the community to learn more about the candidates and what their individual stances on current issues are The forums are open to all parties running and all candidates have been invited to participate The second scheduled forum Alabama House will be held on April in the City of Oxford at the Oxford Performing Arts Center n nThe Calhoun Journal will be submitting a list of questions to the moderators for random selection The questions will be gathered from the voting community through our website If you wish to have a question asked to the candidates please go to the Candidate Forum page and choose which forum you would like to ask a question people may ask a question for each forum All questions submitted through the website will be printed and delivered to the moderator Neither Calhoun County Journal nor the candidates will have advanced knowledge of which questions will be asked to the candidates during the forum The question form will be closed seven days prior to the event to ensure the moderator has enough time to prepare n nDuring the forum each candidate will have the opportunity to answer the same question and a possible rebuttal if one candidate addresses another candidate directly The candidate s responses will be based on a countdown timer to ensure each person has an equal opportunity to address a question n nThe forums will be open to anyone in the public that would like to attend Covid guidelines are still in effect so if community members would like to attend the event in person make sure to arrive early enough to secure a seat The Calhoun County Journal will also be live streaming the forum for those who can t attend the live event
Kottie Paloma nOpens st March at Saatchi Yates n nHaving lived and worked for several years in Los Angeles San Francisco New York and Berlin Paloma currently lives in Alzenau Germany with his wife and two young children Paloma s paintings explore the darker side of society in a humorous yet poignant and gritty manner Heavily inspired by cave paintings and other archetypal symbols Paloma creates works which look to act as fossils of contemporary life tackling subjects such as politics and human behaviour to unpick the failings of modern society n nThe main body of the work was made in Los Angeles over the Covid pandemic the BLM protests and US political unrest These are satirical portraits of this period n nThe exhibition will see Paloma s work through muddied colour reduction techniques recalling the rawness of the earth and the same primitiveness of the cave paintings that inspire him Offering an unbridled view on people cities carvings the artist calls us home translating different realms as unique symbols within his abstract works n nKottie s paintings are a raw unbridled perspective on our generation his commentary is even more poingiant examining the last three years n nLarissa Kikol Comments n n Between the lines or rather between the characters the atmosphere is tense as nif riots were in the air An atmosphere like the wind described above which not only nblows over these figures but also over the human thing constructions Riots also mean a nre shaping of limbs crosses and other unrecognisable objects Into what no one knows n n n larissa kikol n kottiepaloma n n nPlease join us for the Kottie Paloma Private View nThursday st pm pm

We re moving our work to Please follow n n months ago our team at including on the ground organizers across NY State started this handle to create a place where our communities could quickly access news data and information as more and more New Yorkers became eligible for Covid vaccines When we created this handle less than of New Yorkers had received their first dose Today over have received at least one dose while have completed a vaccine series Getting vaccinated is a crucial step that will help bring this pandemic to an end and as we all know this pandemic is far from over n nWe also know that access to reliable info about Covid vaccines treatments and testing will be a critical healthcare need for years to come So beginning today we ll be closing this handle and moving our Covid work over to our handle which is the main IG handle we use to support our work fighting for more affordable and accessible healthcare n nOver there we ll keep sharing important updates answering your questions breaking down confusing concepts and collaborating with medical professionals This handle ny vaccine ed will no longer be active but all of the content will remain posted to ensure people can continue to access saved posts and IG live conversations n nIf you found this handle to be a useful Covid vaccine resource then please stay connected and follow pandemic isn t over Our work continues

There was an assumption that jobs such as kitchen assistants or front of house would pay minimum wage however we are currently carrying vacancies that are offering rates starting at an hour n nIt s been a tumultuous two years in Scotland s hospitality sector n nBrexit induced staff shortages have been compounded by the pandemic and subsequent lockdown restrictions n nThere were dire warnings of the collapse of a sector that directly employs around of Scotland s workforce and with another employed indirectly this means around people rely on the sector to make a living n nWhile the impact of Brexit is still playing out the announcement by the Scottish Government of an end to vaccine passports and an end to all Covid restrictions later this month means that better time lie ahead n nThe only fly in the ointment is staff shortages n nAccording to UK Hospitality Scotland there were between vacancies in the sector at the end of last year meaning up to of jobs in the industry are currently vacant n nEight out of ten businesses report vacancies in roles such as reception and waiting staff while almost have vacancies for chefs with a third reporting staff shortages for kitchen staff housekeepers and even management roles n nAll of which means that there has never been a better time to find a job in hospitality and with businesses competing in a limited pool of applicants wages which were traditionally at the lower end of the market are on a definite upward trend n nPay rates have changed significantly in recent times n nThere used to be an assumption that jobs such as kitchen assistants or front of house would pay near minimum wage however we are currently carrying vacancies that are offering rates starting at an hour by businesses throughout the Highlands and Islands n nThere is little doubt that if you choose to work in hospitality anywhere in Scotland you ve already chosen the perfect location Find all the latest hospitality vacancies on HIJOBS at
