Teacher Retention and Recruitment Our excellent teachers and staff are one of our most valuable resources in education A quality teacher or staff member can make all of the difference between a successful and unsuccessful year for a student However in the last few years our teachers have been asked to do so much They had to switch to online learning at a moment s notice while dealing with technology shortages and lack of home internet This was accomplished with little to no additional training and without additional compensation for the many extra hours of work they gave in addition to their regular work hours Many gave up most of their summer without pay to help create an entirely new world in education Next teachers were tasked with providing both online and in person learning often at the same time even within one class period Our teachers and staff members were literally building the plane while flying it in the air n nThis type of task juggling pushed our teachers and staff past any boundaries they had reached before with technology and learning Simultaneously due to necessary Covid protocols students and teachers were quarantined for over a week when exposed while teaching and learning in person and that had to be factored in to lesson plans Sub shortages only complicated this matter requiring many teachers to work their off periods to cover other classes and teach classes with double the typical number of students to make sure all students had a teacher to supervise them again without additional compensation n nAll the while our teachers were barraged by the politics of Covid infection rates Covid Safety Protocols mask wearing and vaccines They were accused of not wanting to come back to work even of being lazy They were accused of being pro mask or anti mask pro vaccine or anti vaccine n nTo say the least it has been a tough few years and we are seeing record numbers of teachers leave the profession Retaining our best and brightest teachers is of critical importance One of the areas I have looked into is teacher salaries and while we as a district are above average once you have taught in our district for over years our starting salary is lower than many surrounding districts Salaries make up of our district budget I would like to look at ways that our district can be offer competitive salaries to recruit new teachers At the same time offering our existing teachers extra support like the Covid Bonus last year are things that need to be considered By balancing the needs of newer and existing teachers with competitive salaries and compensation we can excel in our goal to employ excellent educators and staff members in our district a primary need to maintain our standing as an excellent district to both work and learn in
This past week Congress received President Biden s trillion budget for a month behind schedule which includes requests for more Covid aid despite states still having billions of unspent federal dollars in their coffers from past stimulus and recovery bills If that is not bad enough the president also seems to have made his calculations assuming that some version of his Build Back Better legislation had passed despite it being stalled in Congress n The president also wants a minimum tax on income and unrealized capital gains for families worth more than million The House passed the MORE Act which would legalize marijuana at the federal level and impose an initial tax on purchases The bill would need votes to break a Senate filibuster where the prospects for passage are not strong Members of the Senate negotiated and agreed to a deal for billion in pandemic aid half the size that the White House requested The lack of funding for international vaccine efforts has angered Democrats and could complicate passage in the House n nRead more in our weekly newsletter gapol ga ga th ga thdistrict gapolitics Congress republican

From AIDs to SARS to Covid Dr Julie Gerberding has helped manage decades of public health crises as a physician director of the CDC and now Merck s Chief Patient Officer One common thread and one she is determined to overcome is inequities in access to information medicines and treatments In this Vanguard Network dialogue Dr Gerberding shares her vision for improving access and efficacy in spite of the ripple effect of the pandemic n nYou can tune in to Healthcare Equity with Dr Julie Gerberding here leadership strategy Executiveleadership leadershipdevelopment Globalleader

I wrote to the Greenock Telegraph in March about my concerns that not all school children had devices despite the promises of the Scottish Government to provide them Here is our press release nLiberal Democrats demand Sturgeon delivers on online learning pledges Inverclyde Liberal Democrats are increasingly concerned about the growing gap in educational attainment and educational access in Inverclyde At the end of last year the SNP government chose to redistribute the million fund set aside for the poorest pupils in the Challenge Authorities and shared it equally between all authorities This pot had been an attempt to close the ever increasing attainment gap and its removal was a slap in the face for equal opportunities and fairness nThis was following on from two years of educational disruption due to the pandemic where wealthier families were able to offset some of the difficulties of home schooling by having access to the internet laptops and other devices However for many poorer families who did not even have one device to share nor internet access the disruption to their children s education was catastrophic When home schooling became mandatory in the lockdown the SNP government did not supply laptops to children who were without them nDr Jacci Stoyle who is a former teacher and current Inverclyde Lib Dem council candidate said n In March Nicola Sturgeon promised devices for every school child to help tackle the digital divide I am totally shocked that two years since the start of the pandemic the SNP Government still hasn t sorted out providing devices and internet access for children from poorer backgrounds Nicola Sturgeon s pre election promise has failed to materialise n The use of online devices for delivering the curriculum has become normal practice even for young children Primary teachers with pupils as young as five have been providing homework tasks reading books and other material online How is this fair if not every child has access to these critical learning tools n We know that pupils are still absent due to Covid isolations online access is critical during these periods to allow pupils to keep in touch with their teachers Local families deserve better nInverclyde schools have recently sent out a survey offering a loaned device but have no opportunities to facilitate online access The communication reads n Inverclyde Community Learning and Development CLD have a number of laptops they can loan to families who need support with technology at home Unfortunately they cannot support access to the internet at the moment If you feel your family could benefit from this and you meet CLD criteria then please fill out the form below Thanks nDr Stoyle said n This really isn t good enough and I call upon Stuart MacMillan MSP to make good the promise which the First Minister made in March last year

COVID has worsened a workforce crisis that affects nearly every human services field putting Pennsylvania s most vulnerable residents at risk
If you cannot work due to COVID you may qualify for up to hours of supplemental paid sick leave with up to of those hours available only when an employee or family member tests positive for COVID Regardless of your immigration status you have a right to take time off from work with pay if you get sick and to a safe and healthy workplace Click to learn more Si no puede trabajar debido a COVID puede calificar para hasta horas de horas de enfermedad pagada suplementarias con hasta de esas horas disponibles s lo cuando un empleado o miembro de la familia da positivo por COVID Independientemente de su estado migratorio tiene derecho a ausentarse del trabajo con horas de enfermedad pagadas y a un lugar de trabajo seguro y saludable Haz click para obtenga m s informaci n

This is BlackMaternalHealthWeek April a time to talk about the importance of strengthening healthcare for Black moms and addressing the disparities in health outcomes for pregnant people n nThe reality is that Black mothers are currently more than three times more likely to die from pregnancy related complications than their white counterparts regardless of income or education The pandemic has only added to these disparities as Black communities have been disproportionately affected by Covid n nAt MACA we re committed to helping build a better healthcare system that s safe and equitable for Black moms and Black families One that provides equal access to healthcare as well as basic needs like nutrition housing education and employment opportunities that can strengthen and build healthier communities everywhere BMHW

to manage every crisis after it hits with reckless incompetence The much needed leadership is nonexistent and as the situation of every crisis worsens all we get are warnings one after another n nBiden warns gas prices will go up then tells the reporter to blame Putin Buttigieg recommends buying an electric vehicle We are told to expect cyber attacks and that we should ensure proper firewalls are in place Hypersonic missiles nuclear weapons chemical attacks nothing is off the table with Putin and we must be prepared for the worst NATO is at risk World War III is one shot away And of course there is Fauci with his never ending COVID mantra Every news cycle brings another warning Americans are desperate for leadership and all they get is incompetence n nWashington has become the new Captain Obvious Our houses are flooding and they say it is going to rain Always a day late and a dollar short But not a single remedy not a sliver of leadership not a shred of a plan that might prevent or even predict a disaster We must settle for platitudes stupid excuses and political propaganda that rivals even the most totalitarian governments America is still the greatest nation on Earth but it is not easy to remain optimistic n nThere is a way out however but we will have to be vigilant and patient We must send the right people to Washington Take back the House and Senate this year and then lay the final brick of normalcy by taking back the White House in In the meantime we plan push back and persevere It is their America or ours I vote for ours VoteMerk com

Teachers are frontline responders to students urgent needs stemming not only from appallingly common gun violence but from the ravages of poverty which affects half of all public school students the mental health crisis that predated COVID and the social emotional and academic impacts of the pandemic Most teachers and support staff are not trained to be nurses psychologists mediators or magicians But often that s what they are called on to do n nHere s AFT President Randi Weingarten s latest column
On Monday the Ohio Restaurant Association endorsed Republican Mike DeWine for Governor at the Tony Packo s in East Toledo n n As of Monday morning the Lucas County Health Department has confirmed infections and deaths from COVID in Lucas County Vaccines have been distributed to of the population n n On Tuesday Toledo City Council voted unanimously to approve the creation of seven new community entertainment districts in downtown Toledo enabling more liquor licenses to be issued Council also approved a settlement with a woman who was seriously injured when a Toledo Police car ran a red light and ran into her vehicle in n n Also on Tuesday the Lucas County Commissioners voted to provide million toward the YWCA of Northwest Ohio s million renovation plan using federal funds received from the American Rescue Plan Act ARPA Commissioners also voted to match from Metroparks Toledo to expand the University Parks Trail by miles from Silica Drive to Centennial Road in Sylvania n n In further Tuesday news the city government announced the installation of a new trash trapping net in the Ottawa River near Stickney and Matzinger A total of seven such nets will be installed throughout Toledo by the end of the year thanks to in federal funding from the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative GLRI n n On Friday the Ohio Department of Transportation completed repairs on the Craig Street Bridge a drawbridge connecting downtown to East Toledo which had gotten stuck in the up position on March following the failure of an outdated electrical component n n Following student protests and parent complaints the private company now administering parking at the University of Toledo ParkUToledo has fired on individual hired a new communications manager and adjusted its policies Parking tickets can now be appealed and reviewed in person and free minute parking zones have been set up for students to be dropped off or picked up n n The Toledo Museum of Art is planning to put three pieces up for auction through Sotheby s on May with the intention of using the anticipated million in revenue to purchase more diverse artwork The pieces in question are C zanne s Clairi re The Glade Matisse s Fleurs ou Fleurs devant un portrait and Renoir s Nu s essuyant n n On Saturday April at AM the Phoenix Earth Food Co op W Sylvania will be breaking ground on a new community garden on an empty adjacent lot it recently acquired n n Next Monday April the City of Toledo s Department of Housing Community Development will host a rental assistance workshop from PM to PM at the Mott Branch Library Dorr St The event will help individuals apply for rental assistance through the Emergency Rental Assistance Program ERAP which is taking applications through Friday April For more information visit I love talking with my friend Pat because he s full of surprising wisdom and he really helps me think things though sometimes n nOnce after a session where Pat had effortlessly given me a number of useful insights I thanked him and asked him if he had any problems or worries of his own Pat mused for a moment and then said Well if I could take even half of my own advice I d have millions of dollars and be president Or at least be able to calmly turn down the job offer n nWhy are we so bad at listening to our own wisdom sometimes n nI thought of that again when I stumbled across the text of an interview I gave a couple of years ago for another friend of mine who teaches philosophy classes The interview was from the year B C as in Before Covid It was given just before the pandemic came along to turn everything upside down Another time another age n nI felt like I d received a gift from the past And shockingly I had sent it to myself like a time capsule n nReading that interview from two years was like tuning in to a transmission from a calmer time A calmer Tim That too I was clearly in a good place B C and able to reflect More grounded more centered all the things we ve lost since the roaring s sprang on us like a famished lion on a dazed wildebeest n nI wish I would have looked back on these words a few times a day during this rough ride they might have helped reel me in a little and might have been more productive than watching The Queen s Gambit for a third time Well better late than never n nMy friend asked me this What is the purpose of a human being n nMy reply I think you can find a way to be kind A kindness for yourself and a kindness that will lead to helping others I can t think of a better purpose I think it sounds deceptively simple It s not just I ll open the car door for you I m talking about a deeper kindness to not respond to our worst reflexes To offer a genuine hand to someone based on the fact that you know that the practice of kindness will enrich I believe there s no stronger energy that can link itself to other people than the energy of kindness n nI see people who embody that and I envy them I want to be more like that and for that day and even for a week I do a pretty good job because I saw it happen and that reminds me I need more of that to bring me to a better place and space and a better way of thinking and living and doing I speak with a forked tongue because I m amazingly selfish in many ways but I try to balance that n nMy friend asked me if seeing an example of kindness and wanting to emulate it was related to education somehow n nMy answer Oh yes There are two types of educators There are educators who like to measure and there are educators who like to teach And I find that a very clear divide Kindness is not measuring Why do we want children to compete against each other and why are we measuring them I find it to be a great enemy of free thinking an enemy of kindness of mentorship of coaching I find it an enemy of love This incessant need to only measure as a way to define someone s capability that is a box a trap that is a cage around a young mind that has yet to experiment fail flourish and conquer and fail again and conquer again and that is a crime against minds That is deeply unkind n nAnother thing I talked about in the interview was not letting fear doubt and uncertainty hold you back n nAs a dyslexic and someone whose primary way of learning is through people when I was in college I still remember the Psychology class I took It was a person lecture hall and every time the teacher would say something I didn t understand I would raise my hand I raised my hand so often people booed Can you imagine being a freshman in college and being booed And you know what I kept my hand up I paid for my seat I know how I learn I got an A in that class Raise your hand and don t be afraid of the boos n nTo which I would add Also don t boo others when they re trying to learn We all learn at different paces and in different ways These are turbulent times but if we ve learned nothing else from the past two years it should be the value of patience and helping each other move forward As for me I m going to try to do more listening to others as well as to my better self

can best represent these voters I wanted to share a recent exchange I had with one such voter as I was campaigning in the Turkey Creek Precinct area nVoter Where do you stand on Right to Life nMe That is perhaps my biggest passion the sanctity of life nVoter How about the nd amendment nMe I have a lifetime gun carry permit nVoter The st amendment nMe It is the foundation for our and any democracy and it is under attack in our country today nVoter Where do you stand on COVID nMe It s been completely mishandled at the national and state governments and at many employers The government and your employer should have no say in the decisions you make regarding your health nVoter Well you have my vote I ll put your postcard up on our refrigerator nMe Thank you nSo you now know more about me and where I stand on some very significant issues but that is not why you or this voter should vote for me As a potential member of the Kosciusko County Council I will have no ability to impact you or anyone on these issues that this voter was most interested in What I can impact and why you should vote for me is that I m an astute businessman and that I will commit to treating your tax dollars as I treat my own money with great conservatism and frugality Our county for the past years have spent more than we ve taken in That trend cannot continue And the answer is NOT to raise your taxes but rather to find ways to balance the budget with more attention on our expenses That is why I respectfully ask for your vote After successfully running the biggest standalone business within Zimmer Biomet for the past years the Global Knee Business with an annual expense budget of over M I have the experience that matters and will bring that expertise to the County Council like no other candidate can nThank you for your thoughtful consideration n nPaid for by Todd Davis for County Council

This Spring Art League will be presenting Peter Dallos Flowering a series of metal sculptures of flowers in varying stages of blooming The collection an evocative and powerful collection explores the beautiful yet sometimes spindly and bizarre forms of orchids and forest flowers n nDallos previous works explored dystopian themes such as the helplessness felt by individuals during war His previous series include Struggle and End of the Road His sculpture War series a commentary on his own experiences in Hungary during World War II and the subsequent rise of the communist regime is in the permanent collection of the Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington DC n nFlowering was inspired during his isolation at his North Carolina cabin during the pandemic I m trying to gentle me down says Dallos Unexpectedly the full isolation during the Covid year made me tranquil Consequently I moved on from the existential worries of previous work The beauty of flowers engages me now n nDallos success as a sculptor comes after years spent as a professor of neuroscience at Northwestern University He has written an autobiography I Was Here Life Science and Art in Turbulent Times n nPeter Dallos Flowering will be on display April May An artist s reception free and open to the public will be held on Wednesday April pm

In Israel LIFE and DEATH moments are being faced constantly today right NOW n nIn the past year there have been more emergency medical calls made than EVER before in the nation s history n nParamedics and emergency medical technicians MUST RESPOND to every single call for help They must triage the injured stop the bleeding from fatal wounds restart hearts that have ceased to beat evacuate critical Covid patients and so much more n nThis work cannot stop nor can it slow And to do it they need an overflowing stream of medical supplies and equipment In Israel these things are provided almost exclusively by the generous donations of others largely from FRIENDS in America n nWhen you make a donation of ANY AMOUNT to help provide the urgent professional medical supplies that Israelis cannot live without we will send you one of our ISRAEL FIRST AID KITS as a token of our appreciation n nThis kit contains a variety of household first aid supplies such as multiple types of personal bandages gauze tape tweezers alcohol prep pads scissors safety gloves cotton swabs and more n nWhen you give to help Israel s emergency response teams save the most critically wounded and desperate patients we want to give you this kit to help in the small emergencies of your life n nPlease give right now EVERY DOLLAR SAVES LIVES

Today I visited several Sheltered housing complexes in my ward to speak to tenants n nCovid has impacted the mental health of our aging population who were shielding in sheltered housing and most tenants still remain stuck in their flats due to social anxiety n nCurrently there is a lack of care workers in the council to provide adequate support for these tenants due to a shortage of staff resulting from low numbers of applicants applying for vacancies n nThis is why yesterday Aberdeen Labour pledged to fight for care workers to be paid an hour to end poverty pay and ensure the work they do is fully valued We want to see an end to care charges and proper support for unpaid carers n nWe want a National Care Service to deliver minimum standards in elderly care but we believe it is vital that local councils should be given the funding and powers to raise standards and that services should continue to be accountable to local elected members carers and those who use care not to unelected officials or central government in Edinburgh

Digital transformation for higher education post COVID n nHigher Education Institutions or HEIs have been forced to reconfigure their activities as a result of the pandemic Based on new research Prof Lloyd George Waller argues that the difference between the institutions success or otherwise in moving online depends on their digital readiness and resilience which in turn depends on their digital transformation strategy n nListen now n n

When the Philippines went into strict COVID lockdown Nemia s husband lost his job as a tricycle driver Sales at her small convenience store plummeted She found herself struggling to feed herself and provide for her family n nThen in June Grameen launched a project using cryptocurrency platform to help women microentrepreneurs like Nemia get back on their feet Learn how it worked by tapping our profile link
Stoneleigh Fellow Dr Jessica Beard her research team at the Lewis Katz School of Medicine at Temple University have uncovered changes in the people and places impacted by interpersonal firearm violence following COVID containment measures in Philadelphia including a rise in the percentage of mass shootings and in the proportion of women and children who were victims of gun violence n nThrough her Fellowship Dr Beard is working to deepen the media narrative on gun violence to educate the public on its root causes and solutions

If you liked Mothers x Mothers and Vaccination Is you ll love NoJudgment the latest collaboration between NRC RIM and nonprofit design firm IDEO org n n NoJudgment is a toolkit that offers resources for community based organizations and individuals to help de escalate the often polarized conversations that are taking place around the COVID vaccine among young people in refugee immigrant and migrant RIM communities n nThe toolkit was designed with public health actors and community based organizations in mind and was created in partnership with a Youth Design Collective consisting of five young people who we ll hear from during this upcoming webinar n nBy using the tools in NoJudgment we hope you can invite youth in your community to engage in meaningful conversations around the COVID vaccine After completing this webinar you will be able to n n Co design vaccine confidence materials with youth in your community n n Support youth and young adults in having conversations with their peers about COVID vaccines n n Spark curiosity and conversations among youth in your community with online tools n n Host gatherings of youth to have these conversations in real time n nPreview the toolkit in advance at

Hey Community members and business owners Please read our petition If you d like to sign it the link is below If you have questions reach out n n also in bio n nWe are writing to you on behalf of a petition in regards to the City of Cheney You may not have heard about the American Rescue Plan Act that awarded funds to cities to offset covid related expenses and losses Cheney has received just under million in funding The purpose for funding is to help local business and communities n nSo far Cheney has awarded about towards infrastructure They have also approved another million for infrastructure that has not been allocated yet There has been ONLY of the million that has been allocated community members and towards the revitalization of downtown Cheney which could potentially end up being sidewalk maintenance There has been ZERO allocation or investment into local businesses n nThe city of Spokane has held public forums to discuss their allocation of funds whereas Cheney has had ZERO Spokane has also hired a secondary accounting firm to make sure that funds follow correct ARPA guidelines we would recommend similar due diligence by the City of Cheney to ensure proper use of funds nOur goal is to unite local businesses and community members by signing a petition to stop the allocation of funds until public opinions are heard n nIf you feel the city needs to be transparent with the use of these funds and hold public forums it is vital that you please add your name business to our petition

Exciting News n nI am thrilled to announce that we have a special film screening happening at Bethel Church Twin View on April th n nWe will be watching the award winning documentary Tending Clouds which tells the extraordinary story of the victorious overcomer and trafficking survivor Reaksmey Haas nWhen Reaksmey was eight years old she was sold by her mother to an American pedophile She was later rescued and brought into the care of Agape International Missions Despite enduring horrific trauma she and several other minors dared to testify against their abuser in a historic trial that resulted in a year prison sentence Now a young adult Reaksmey has started her own business and is working in Cambodia to free girls from the very bondage she endured While rebuilding her life she once again has to testify against her abuser in a retrial during the height of the COVID Pandemic Tending Clouds tenderly tells the story of a woman of great courage who refuses to allow tragedy to define her nWe will be joined by Northern California Anti Trafficking Coalition Agape International Missions Justice Collective and Terina Dutton of Yasha Global Home and One Heart Global This is a night to gather as a community to discover our part in fighting this evil nMark your calendars for April th The film starts at and the doors will open shortly beforehand More details in the coming days Please invite all your friends nLink for trailer in my bio
In a federal review the Minneapolis based organ procurement organization serving Minnesota and the Dakotas has fallen from a designation of underperforming to failing The organization says the slip reflects an off year due to the COVID pandemic and that it is expanding its clinical staff The review is designed to shorten the nation s organ waitlists If LifeSource remains at the same level in it will lose its certification n n

We re dressing casual for a cause to make a difference in our communities Project Sanctuary received donated by employees and the Bank as our March Casual For A Cause Denim Days beneficiary We are proud of the support we have been able to provide to local non profit organizations since this effort began in with donations totaling n nProject Sanctuary is a private not for profit organization with the mission to prevent domestic violence and sexual assault in Mendocino County through advocacy crisis response community collaboration education awareness and shelter They aid over individuals annually with a variety of free services including but not limited to Crisis counseling group counseling legal advocacy and hour emergency response Throughout the pandemic since Project Sanctuary has seen an increase of over of people in need of their crisis services While working remotely and following Mendocino County CDC guidelines regarding COVID Project Sanctuary has continued to maintain services for shelters emergency financial assistance emergency food protective order preparation court advocacy emergency crisis counseling and sexual assault response Project Sanctuary provides a trained advocate to speak to hours a day days a week

Frome West Candidate Martin Dimery is currently a County Councillor elected in nHe proposed along with John Clarke the other Green County Councillor successful motions on the ban on single use plastics in county run institutions requested the government move Covid Test and Trace away from commercial operators into the hands of council public health experts advocated the declaration of a Climate Emergency took up a number of local causes including protecting the personal support given to young people with physical and learning disabilities initiating a parking review of Frome and helping release substantial grants to Frome Town Council towards improving highways and cycle tracks in the Frome area n nMartin has been actively engaged on the Children and Families Scrutiny committee dealing with the education fostering and social welfare of children He has been a major voice in demanding that Frome no longer be the forgotten town of Somerset ensuring that the area receives its fair share of the resources available This was particularly important when lobbying for Test and Trace centres to be set up in the town during the Covid outbreaks n nMartin regularly attends meetings at Frome Town and Selwood Parish councils supporting their needs and concerns He is an active supporter of the Mayday Saxonvale development and recently spoke on behalf of the local communities campaigning against the over expansion of the quarries in the Nunney Chantry and Mells areas He stood as one of the Green Party candidates for South West England in the last EU Election when the party achieved a creditable third place overall ahead of both Conservatives and Labour n nMartin is familiar to many in Frome as a former teacher at Frome College who went on to become Programme Manager at the Cheese and Grain hall and Creative Director of the Frome Festival He and his wife Anne first moved to Frome in and their three children attended local schools They now have three granddaughters and take an active part in the cultural life of the town It was one of my proudest contributions to life in Frome when John Clarke and I became two out of the three Somerset County councillors representing the area says Martin The Green Party has since gone on to increase its representation on Mendip District from three to ten councillors several of whom will be standing for the new Somerset Council If elected we have a duty to ensure that Frome s distinctive voice is heard on all matters to help make the town as well resourced prosperous and environmentally friendly as possible for the benefit of generations to come

Profs and Pints DC presents Cities After Covid an examination of how the pandemic has altered the status and future of urban centers with John Rennie Short geographer scholar of urban issues and professor of public policy at the University of Maryland Baltimore County n nOne need not walk far through Washington D C to see how the pandemic has impacted different sections of the city and even businesses and people within them in very different ways Some neighborhoods have barely a trace of their former activity while others are bustling Thriving businesses stand next to boarded storefronts Office buildings remain mostly empty and parts of town feel more dangerous The housing market is in a huge period of flux n nAre our nation s cities going to return to the way they were If not what will the post pandemic city look like n nCome hear such questions tackled by Dr John Rennie Short a geographer who has extensively monitored and written about the changes that cities have undergone since Covid first hit here in the late winter of He ll give an overview of what we know looking at population shifts and how differences in U S and European approaches to pandemic relief had markedly different impacts on cities He ll examine the health of downtown businesses and look at crime trends and their impact n nLooking forward he ll discuss how cities are likely to be altered by more people working from home companies settling into hybrid work weeks and consumers greater reliance on online shopping He ll also discuss the role played by the distinct characteristics of specific cities and whether cities with a substantial creative class are likely to bounce back better than others n nThe obituary of the American cities has been written before both the invention of the telephone and the terrorist attacks led some to declare them doomed Will they recover this time enough to someday regard the pandemic as temporary setback Advance tickets Doors save with a student ID Listed time is for doors Talk starts minutes later Please allow yourself time to place any orders and get seated and settled in Bring proof of vaccination and a mask as they may be required in response to local infection rates The Bier Baron will be requiring event attendees to purchase a minimum of two items which can be food or beverages including soft drinks

HIPAA the acronym for the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act has come up a lot since the beginning of the COVID pandemic You may have seen people on social media or news shows discussing their HIPAA rights regarding masks or vaccinations In short HIPAA is a federal law that protects patients sensitive health information from being disclosed without their knowledge or consent

The Mackinac Center worked with Pulitzer Prize winning journalist Charlie LeDuff last year to investigate how well the state tracked COVID deaths in nursing homes Our initial findings suggested that as many as of all Michigan COVID deaths could be tied to a long term care facility Seeing our investigation the House Oversight Committee called on the Office of the Auditor General to review the state s data The resulting report shows that the Whitmer administration miscounted deaths among Michigan s vulnerable and elderly population

April is National Child Abuse Prevention Month and it s an important time to talk about the online exploitation of children Today children are spending more time on the internet During the COVID pandemic there has been a dramatic increase in reports of online exploitation n n In alone reports of online enticement to the National Center for Missing Exploited Children NCMEC s CyberTipline grew by compared to Online video games have been very popular for years and are especially popular now n nBecause of social distancing precautions more and more children especially boys are playing online video games for entertainment and to socialize with friends n nStart the conversation and do some research Talking about online sexual exploitation can be hard so NCMEC developed resources to help NCMEC offers a variety of tools to help jumpstart talking to your children about online safety and signs of potential online exploitation Parental involvement is critical when it comes to helping children game more safely n nIf you re being abused or have been abused please call the Betty Griffin Center hour crisis hotline at or TTY users dial n n

This paper provides ten policy proposals for mitigating the economic fallout of the COVID pandemic including both positive reforms and warnings about pitfalls that are likely to make the situation worse

Broadband Internet nA topic that is hurled out there every election cycle is what are you going to do to bring jobs to this county The question seems to have been dwarfed this cycle by flooding and traffic congestion however here s a thought n nOur Federal Government has gone off the deep end with making inadequate and irresponsible legislation making us conservatives nervous as to what the future will hold The cost of living is rising faster than our wages People are scrambling to find ways to save their wages in order to keep up with inflation n nOf all the programs that are on the horizon to be forced upon us one may be useful n nI am speaking of broadband internet service As we went through COVID we saw a great swing to work from home opportunities I have been speaking with people who are happy about working from home and enjoying benefits such as spending more time with family saving money by curbing commuting expenses and raises they have achieved by working jobs that are outside the county and sometimes out of state jobs that were otherwise unavailable due to physical location This could be the solution to our families concerns Those concerns being their children are leaving and not returning because there are too few well paying jobs n nBroadband internet would also benefit rural college students whose parents are making sacrifices to ensure their children can excel in a competitive job market Because most classes and supporting software run off highspeed internet these students are having to drive to locations with faster internet sources to study such as Starbucks Panera Bread or Whataburger n nBroadband will also open doors by allowing uninterrupted video class meets and faster material uploads for online schools certifications or accreditations in a number of fields which can lead to advancement in a current job or better jobs in fields they are passionate about I know this personally n nCurrently rural businesses within our county are struggling with the lack of dependable internet connectivity Examples of these struggles include the inability to run a debit credit card machine at our local rural businesses and cell phone hotspots that are not reliable enough for a debit credit card machine either Losing connections can delay invoicing ordering and causes miscommunication which is detrimental to independent businesses located throughout our beautiful county n nAnother sector affected by unreliable internet connectivity is home based employees An example is those who work for Navy Federal one of the area s largest employers of at home based employees that pays above average wages Employees have expressed the fear and frustration of always having to explain to Navy Federal that the internet was awful and unreliable while praying daily that Navy Federal continues to have patience with them Based on my observation of the housing market climbing so rapidly over the last two years I do not believe that the solution is sell out and move into town after all there are no houses in town to move to n nWith the addition of broadband not only could it make stable these examples and more like them but it could also lead to a more technical workforce living and spending their income here in our county Possibly a much better scenario is it promotes families to live in a slower country setting allowing them to focus more on the family and find the joy we already know n nDuring my trip to Greenville SC a friend was showing me how their community took its abandoned textile factories and rundown buildings to re invent the city s town life Local investors using their money invested in their town and attracted a younger tech driven crowd This crowd successfully changed and bred new life into a gloomy depressed part of town n nWith the state jockeying a position to receive million dollars or more this seems to have some promise in making some positive influences in our beloved county This is just something to work towards with the help of us all

Move to End Wolf Emergency Declaration n nJUN n nHARRISBURG The York County delegation to the House of Representatives joined fellow members Tuesday to end the more than three month long emergency declaration which gave Gov Tom Wolf sweeping powers when they approved House Resolution n nDelegation members Reps Seth Grove R Dover Dawn Keefer R Dillsburg Kate Klunk R Hanover Keith Gillespie R Hellam Mike Jones R York Township and House Appropriations Chairman Stan Saylor R Red Lion issued the following statement n n Our form of government is rooted in checks and balances to protect citizens When one branch of government becomes too powerful one or both of the other two branches must step up to keep the other branch in check so government is balanced n n The Legislature is an important and equal part of government Unfortunately it has been sidestepped for the past three months We attempted time and again to collaborate with the governor by reaching out to him directly and passing viable and meaningful legislation to address COVID Instead of working with members of the General Assembly the governor opted to instead take directives from a small group of like minded governors who represent other states ignoring the voices of Pennsylvania n n The governor s own actions indicate the dangers from COVID are subsiding The administration has lifted restrictions across the Commonwealth and just last week the governor took part in a protest that included hundreds of people Despite these actions he extended the declaration for an additional days which would have kept it in place for half a year n n An emergency declaration provides extraordinary powers to the governor so dangers can be addressed swiftly It is not meant to be a long term situation n nWith passage of House Resolution the emergency declaration is slated to end Friday n nYork County Republican Delegation

Research suggests that the rates of elder abuse in the United States have nearly doubled during the pandemic affecting one in five older persons writes Allie Yang Green senior manager at Equal Justice Works A public health crisis and a human rights issue elder abuse is one of the most prevalent forms of abuse in the country and it has only worsened since the onset of the COVID pandemic n nIn observance of National Crime Victims Rights Week we re sharing stories of how our Elder Justice Program Fellows have advocated for abuse victims in predominantly rural communities throughout the country Since Fellows have assisted close to older adults helping to address unmet legal needs stemming from abuse Combining direct legal services with extensive education and outreach activities in their communities Fellows in the Elder Justice Program are helping to improve the national response to elder abuse and create a society where all people regardless of age can live with dignity and security n nHear from Fellows Caitlin Corey hosted by Northwest Texas Legal Assistance and Benjamin Taylor hosted by Legal Aid Society of Louisville in a new blog on our website

Campaign funding tallies in tens of thousands nBy Mitchell Kirk Daily R eportermkirk greenfieldreporter com nApril n nHANCOCK COUNTY Tens of thousands of dollars are backing campaigns in the upcoming primary election including from residents candidates themselves and companies doing business with county government n nReports due earlier this month document campaigns contributions and expenditures dating back to the beginning of the year n nMarc Huber a Republican seeking reelection for his Hancock County Board of Commissioners District seat came into the reporting period with nearly and tallied nearly more in contributions n nHuber who s running for a third term on the board of commissioners said his campaign had a couple fundraisers in preparation for next week s election n n That s usually what we ve always done in the past he said We ve had some corporate people invest in our campaign and we ve had local people invest in it as well n nAmong those corporate contributors are companies and executives of companies with speculative warehouse developments in western Hancock County including from Columbia South Carolina based Red Rock Developments and each from Carmel based Lauth John Bumgarner of Cincinnati based Al Neyer and Ryan Gallmeyer of Indianapolis based Ambrose Property Group n nHuber has supported much of the speculative warehouse development in the western part of the county but not all He voted against the creation of a special taxing district last year to facilitate a Red Rock Developments project citing a lack of assurances that it would benefit public safety and schools The commissioners have since adopted a practice of entering into economic development agreements with warehouse developers that outline tax breaks as well as payments for operational public safety and school purposes n nLaw firms and lawyers involved in the western developments have contributed to Huber s campaign as well including from Matthew Price of Dentons Indianapolis office and another from an investment company he runs from Barnes Thornburg s Indianapolis office and from Briane House of Greenfield based Pritzke Davis n nDustin Frye of Fishers based RQAW which is leading construction on the county s soon to open new jail contributed to Huber s campaign n n It s not that uncommon Huber said If you look at anybody s campaign financing people that work for the county and do things for the county they tend to contribute It s not a payoff n nIndiana Rep Chris Jeter R Fishers whose district includes part of northwestern Hancock County contributed to Huber s campaign as well n nGary McDaniel a Republican Greenfield City Council member looking to replace Huber came into the reporting period with nearly and raised another His backers include fellow city council members George Plisinski and Mitch Pendlum as well as Ray Richardson who served as county attorney for years before the board of commissioners replaced him in n nDavid Clapper and Sandra Hudson western county residents and outspoken critics of the development there also supported McDaniel n nMcDaniel has been critical of that development as well arguing that the infrastructure in that area is lacking for such large complexes n n It s unbelievable that we can go at something this unprepared he said I hope to work with the other commissioners and we can step back for a minute and see what we can do to make the lives of the taxpayers better n nMore focus needs to be placed on residential development in the western part of the county McDaniel said n nMuch of Republican incumbent Hancock County Prosecutor Brent Eaton s campaign coffers consists of a loan of over from himself He said he started setting money aside more than a year ago n n Had to tighten the belt a little bit around the house and that s just the way it is Eaton said n nHe noted COVID risks that persisted through the winter made it challenging to hold fundraising events n n It was very difficult to have the type of in person events which have been the lifeblood of campaign fundraising in the past he said n nGrey Chandler a Republican looking to replace Eaton reported over in contributions much of which from family and himself He also reported a loan from himself to his campaign n n I like the idea that I don t owe anybody any favors he said I m not saying other candidates who fund raise would feel that way but I think it s a lot easier when there s no issues like that I certainly accepted donations from those who reached out and wanted to give but I didn t make serious fundraising efforts n nChandler a former Madison County deputy prosecutor added he s reached out to lawyers he s had good relationships with in the past for donations but has yet to hear back n nAlong with candidates seeking office a public question is also on the ballot for voters in the Mt Vernon Community School Corporation district regarding a new property tax of up to cents per of assessed value from through as late as School officials say the tax is needed as a decade long funding boost allowed by the state draws to a close and as property tax caps continue to limit revenue available to schools It comes as the school corporation embarks on an expansion to keep up with its projected student population growth that includes building a new elementary school n nA committee advocating for the tax increase has raised over for its campaign including from Mt Vernon staff and school board members as well as from the Indiana Kentucky Ohio Regional Council of Carpenters n nMike McCarty a former Mt Vernon school board member and co chair of the Mt Vernon Community Growing Stronger Together committee said even more important than raising funds for the committee has been raising awareness about the needs for the tax increase throughout the school district Chief among those needs he continued is maintaining competitive pay for teachers to ensure the school corporation doesn t lose them and making sure class sizes don t get too big n n Schools are the centers of our communities McCarty said n nAttempts to reach the Indiana Kentucky Ohio Regional Council of Carpenters for comment were unsuccessful McCarty did not want to speak on their behalf but said he s grateful for the group s support n n They re part of the community somehow and feel very strongly obviously he said n nBill Bolander the incumbent Republican Hancock County Council member representing District in the southwestern part of the county reported a sole campaign contribution consisting of a loan from himself n n I ve always funded it myself pretty much said Bolander who s in his sixth term on the council n nBolander added he received a contribution from the Metropolitan Indianapolis Board of Realtors but that it s yet to be deposited He thinks that support stems from his advocacy for higher residential design standards as the council s representative on the Hancock County Area Plan Commission n nScott Wooldridge a Republican looking to replace Bolander came into the reporting period with nearly and raised another n nAlong with McDaniel s campaign Clapper also contributed to Wooldridge s Wooldridge has been critical of the development surge in the western part of the county as well The county council can influence that development via tax abatements something Wooldridge feels Bolander and other council members have been too generous on Wooldridge thinks abatements could be scrutinized more and last shorter durations n n We need to do the people s work and not just our own agendas he said n nClapper a commercial real estate analyst said he supports McDaniel because of his desire to pause on industrial development and think more about residential development and supports Wooldridge because of his promise to put constituents feelings over his own n n I m not against development but it s got to be development that makes sense Clapper said n nJeannine Gray the incumbent Republican Hancock County Council member representing council District came into the reporting period with over and raised another Her opponent Scott Ruble reported an in kind contribution of over to his campaign from his business Ruble Outdoor Concepts Inc

I have overcome unprecedented challenges in my first months as your Clerk In December of I became the rd Clerk of Court in less than two years I came into office months after courts and courthouse offices closed or reduced onsite staff office hours and services due to the COVID pandemic An internal audit requested by me in January revealed major procedural deficiencies within the areas evaluated Thousands of case files had to digitized and destroyed per a change to the rules of recordkeeping criminal expunctions were issued by our District Attorney and processed by our clerk s office within months The State of North Carolina processes about expunctions per year for all NC counties I managed significant policy changes as our state administrative office leadership transitioned from former Chief Justice Cheri Beasley dem to Chief Justice Paul Newby rep and as our local district court leadership transitioned from former Chief District Court Judge Lisa Menefee dem to Chief District Court Judge Victoria Roemer rep And I had to run for re election months after assuming office n nEarly voting starts tomorrow Vote to keep me DENISE HINES as your Forsyth County Clerk of Superior Court My seven years of experience in judicial services here in Forsyth County as a magistrate as your Chief Magistrate and now as your Clerk of Court prepared me with the knowledge skill and confidence to successfully navigate the challenges of this abbreviated year term of office I m seeking one more term as your Forsyth County Clerk of Superior Court During my next term I want to provide the experience and leadership necessary to move our staff and services into our new courthouse this time next year and I need more time to solidify the changes I ve made within our office to improve the knowledge and responsiveness of our clerks to improve our use of and reference to state law and best practice policies to expand community engagement efforts post pandemic and to continue to work with our state IT staff to improve the online services that are available to our community through our state maintained webpage nccourts gov forsyth n nI m Experienced I m Tested I m Proven nVote Denise Hines for Clerk of Superior Court

Re election Announcement nMayor Angie Devanney nApril n nIt s been a trying and difficult few years n nLike many of you there were times that I struggled with so much unknown in the early days of Covid I found strength and inspiration from many places namely my family my mamas Liza Viana with her own struggles my Town hall staff I love you guys with all my heart and Father Andy Prachar who supported me in times of weakness even though I am not Catholic He coined a phrase that will forever send me right back into the memory of those early months of the global pandemic He called that feeling Leadership Tired At the end of the day we all felt the weight the heaviness of the Covid crisis plus the exposure of the wound that social and racial injustice caused all bubbling to the surface simultaneously n nMy family sacrificed While most families were reconnecting over dinner playing board games and cooking together the Devanneys were surviving off of square take out meals a day a mother and wife who spent her time on emergency management calls with the state county and local level until all hours of the day and missing a mom s stabilizing force There were high school graduations proms championship games and dance recital never held A sadness for loss of it all My husband George forged forward and ran our business without me never complaining n nI share these very personal moments because as we emerge from the Covid crisis I had uncertainty about running for re election Not because I don t love the job the hard work and the connection to this community because I most certainly do It was because my family gave selflessly so I could take care of our residents n nWe all are witnessing that Berkeley Heights is in the midst of change Many important projects cultural events and planning will shape what this community will become in the future My local county state and federal relationships my ability to get things done has kept us safe and is helping us grow Recently I had an epiphany this is not the time for a hiatus but rather a time to lean in fully after Covid derailed what we are capable of evolving into as a community n nJust a few highlights come to mind Working with Congressman Malinowki to bring to Berkeley Heights to address the aging infrastructure and drainage issues plaguing the Township Lobbying Union County to ensure the Berkeley Caterers project becomes the gateway jewel of our community providing passive recreation and walking trails along the Passaic Driving innovative ways to fund the redevelopment of Peppertown Park to be the gem of our downtown Negotiating with Fiserve to bring in in funding for the lower Columbia Park development initiative started by volunteers n nTaking care of our seniors by completing vaccine registrations Recording regular robo calls that still take place today so our older adults who may not access technology can easily stay informed Creating a senior survey to ensure that every older resident has a voice in the activities through the creation of a Senior Advisory Committee because Berkeley Heights seniors want to age in place n nRespecting our first responders at the highest level Office of Emergency Management fire and the rescue squad Appointing our new police chief who will continue the work of emphasizing community policing Bringing senior programs like the Mobile Vehicle Commission MVC to the BHPD the parking lot at town hall so our seniors don t have to travel Fighting for accreditation through our municipal insurance company to help to give our police department the tools they need Working with our Mayor s Youth Council to offer self defense training for young women n nCreating an Economic Development Committee that provided support for businesses during shut down Launching a Technical Review Committee to help starting a business in Berkeley Heights easier Passing the creation of an entertainment zone that makes Berkeley Heights a destination Pushing for improvements like green space and biking walking paths in downtown to grow the restaurant and other industries that will service the new residents moving into that area n nKeeping a mindful eye on the finances Hiring a Financial Planner to track debt pay down debt and maintain our financial health Dedicating reserves for snow sewer debt services and more Pushing to ensure redevelopment projects stay on track so that our affordable housing agreement would not be jeopardized and we can pay down the debt on the municipal complex plus permanently finance our debt n nCreating a welcoming community where everyone feels a part of Berkeley Heights Passing a permanent committee the Truth Community Healing Committee Celebrating everyone s culture through community flag raisings events Planning a multicultural street fair in the fall Assessing our diversity and inclusion in Town hall and our commissions and boards n nAdmittedly there were a few groans on Cornell Avenue when I discussed the importance to me of continuing my work in the Township But I know I have the love and support of my family to ensure I keep Berkeley Heights on the forefront n nSo it is with great pride I launch my campaign for re election We have much more to do Berkeley Heights I m looking forward to us all doing it together After all we are better together

ScamAlert Kent residents are being targeted by a banking scam claiming they are from the security team in your bank An automatic caller says your money is being taken from your account for an Amazon voucher and international money transfer n nThis is a SCAM Criminals used phone spoofing to make it look like the call was from a local Ashford number n nDo not respond to cold callers If you are concerned call your bank using the phone number on the back of your card Make sure the line is clear before you dial n nReport scams to Citizens Advice on n nDue to Covid we have seen an increase in scams Please warn friends and family ConnectedCommunities ScamAware

IS OCEAN CITY BETTER OFF UNDER MAYOR JAY GILLIAN S LEADERSHIP nTHE ANSWER IS EASY n nThere s a time honored threshold question that arises in most campaigns for elected office That question is Are you better off now than you were blank years ago n nIn the case of Jay Gillian the blank is filled with a twelve marking his years of service as Mayor The question is one he welcomes and encourages all voters to ask themselves leading up to the May th Municipal Election n nLet s take a look at the conditions and situation in Ocean City today much of which is attributable to Jay s leadership working in Unity with the Community n nINFRASTRUCTURE nWhen Jay first took office the physical infrastructure of the City had deteriorated dramatically There was not even a formally adopted capital plan and hadn t been for years n nJay got to work immediately addressing the most pressing needs and developing a plan for the coming five years This capital plan has been refined and updated annually in partnership with City Council and the community n nToday twelve years later an impressive amount of the City s physical needs have been repaired improved or completely replaced Highlights of this unprecedented attention to infrastructure include paving and drainage improvements on over of the City s miles of roads and alleys improved drainage systems including for the first time huge mechanical pumping systems in several of the most flood prone areas dozens of bulkhead replacements at higher elevations than previously existed a complete replacement of the boardwalk between th and th Streets including new pavilions and restrooms beach and dune maintenance including federally funded island wide beach replenishment for the first time bayfront and lagoon dredging park and recreation improvements including a new skate park a new safe artificial turf field at Carey Stadium an expanded and refurbished Sports and Civic Center playground improvements in all four wards and several large open space purchases along th Street and in the th to th Street area n nFINANCIAL MANAGEMENT TAXES PROPERTY VALUES nOcean City enjoys strong and stable finances including the largest fund balance in City history clean audits strong bond ratings and stabile and reasonable property taxes Property values have increased on average over in the past twelve years n nEMERGENCY MANAGEMENT nDuring Jay s first term the City was severely impacted by Superstorm Sandy But we were ready The community rallied together under Mayor Gillian s leadership and was cleaned up fixed up and back in business faster than any other shore community in New Jersey Other significant hits from Mother Nature came and went in the following years and each time Ocean City did whatever was needed to protect people and property and get things back to normal n nMore recently was the world wide health emergency due to Covid Mayor Gillian didn t take any knee jerk reactions that some were calling for including a demand to close the island completely to visitors He consulted with public health professionals from the local community of medical providers and Shore Medical Center along with partners at the County Health Department and the State of New Jersey and made the tough but prudent decisions that were needed As always Jay provided for the needs of our residents setting up a system to assist those that needed help to make arrangements for their vaccinations when they became available Hundreds of people the majority seniors were helped n nQUALITY OF LIFE nDuring Mayor Gillian s tenure the City s quality of life already the envy of the region has been maintained and improved First and foremost Ocean City continues to be viewed as clean and safe by residents property owners and visitors alike It s no accident that Ocean City is always at the top of any Best of polls or lists including Best Beach Best Family Destination Best Downtown Best Boardwalk and the most tax friendly town for retirees n nMayor Gillian believes quality of life improvements go hand in hand with neighborhood improvements that attract families to live here The drainage and paving improvements in Merion Park for example were followed by significant private investment and construction of new attractive single family housing Many new young families have moved into this neighborhood It s a model that is being duplicated throughout the island n nSo ask yourself is Ocean City better off now than twelve years ago The answer s easy and a resounding yes n nAnd Ocean City is better off now and better off in the future with Jay Gillian as Mayor Vote to reelect Mayor Gillian on May th

If Environmental and Animal Extremist Groups Get Their Way What Will Our Pets Eat n nAs pet owners our dogs and cats are important to us in so many ways One of the most basic and important parts of caring for pets is feeding them Therefore it is important to consider where pet food comes from and what will happen if there is no food available to feed them That could be a real crisis if animal and environmental extremists manage to get their way and animal agriculture were to cease n nIncreased Pets Means Increased Need for Pet Food n nAccording to the American Pet Products Association pet ownership increased to about up from in The Wall Street Journal reported that pet food sales grew almost in the year ending November compared to for food overall Pets and their food are big business So how do we meet the needs of our pets n nThis is where animal proteins and products that aren t utilized by humans come in n nAnimal Byproducts in Pet Food n nPet foods use rendered animal ingredients and by products for pet food These ingredients are not only healthy but improve the sustainability of the pet food industry animal agriculture and add in valuable nutrients n nAt the American Feed Industry Association s AFIA Pet Food Conference in January of the head of food safety quality and regulatory for Pilgrims JBS USA Ansen Pond Ph D provided a detailed account of the sustainable benefits of rendering to the pet food industry n nThese benefits included significant contributions n To reduce animal protein fat and byproduct waste n Repurpose water n Reduce greenhouse gas emissions GHG n Provide fresh meat slurry ingredients to pet food processors n n nEverything But the Moo Oink and Cluck n nAnimal agriculture has a saying that they use everything but the moo or oink or cluck In the U S meals containing different meat and cuts comprise of only a portion of a livestock animal n nThe raw materials from the animals processed are recaptured and repurposed in many industries including pet food where essential amino acids and fatty acids are valuable for pet nutrition n nRoughly of raw materials from cattle from poultry and from swine are considered inedible in the U S market for human food Rather than going to waste those products are used for numerous products ranging from pet food to asphalt suture material gelatin capsules paint make up pharmaceutical products and many many more n nWater Used for Irrigation is a Valuable Byproduct of Animal Processing n nWater used for irrigation is a valuable byproduct of animal agriculture and animal processing When livestock are rendered water is removed from animal byproduct ingredients The water is collected as condensate and then renderers treat and repurpose that water for use in irrigation This equates to billion gallons billion pounds of water released back into the environment every year To put it into perspective that equates to about Mississippi Rivers n nReplacing Animal Protein and Fat Ingredients with Vegan Alternatives is Not Sustainable n nAlmost daily animal and environmental groups are pushing for fake vegan products which are simply not sustainable nor healthy The reality is this if pet food producers were to replace animal protein and fat ingredients which are by products of human food production with vegan alternatives they d have to plant and harvest an additional million acres of soybeans and million acres of corn That doesn t even take into account the additional water needed to grow those crops n nGuardian Article About Vegan Dog Food n nOn April th The Guardian published an article claiming that a peer reviewed study from the University of Winchester proves that vegan diets are healthier for dogs than commercial diets The facts are that no veterinary nutritionists advocate for vegan dog food UNLESS they are formulated by a licensed veterinary nutritionist and there are no other alternatives Cats simply cannot subsist on a vegan diet even though there are those vegans who believe they can A vegan diet for cats is inhumane causing the cat to suffer from malnutrition and a horrible death n nIt is important to note that The Guardian has received numerous grants to write against animal agriculture Therefore it comes as no surprise to find numerous flaws in the so called study and subsequent claims The researchers of the study are vegan and motivated by bias None of the researchers who participated in the study are veterinary nutritionists Most glaring is the fact that the study was funded by the food awareness organization ProVeg International n nThe study itself was based on pet owner responses It was sent to pet owners who were the only ones giving input Their pets veterinarians had no input According to the study of the dogs were fed a conventional meat diet were fed a raw meat diet and were fed a vegan diet over the period of one year nThere were no challenges given in the study either which is a basic part of scientific research The numbers vegan and raw diet are not representative of the general population Additionally the Guardian article glossed over the fact that according to the study raw fed dogs were healthier than vegan dogs n nByproducts Are NOT Bad for Pets n nAnimal byproducts are a sustainable and nutritious way to meet the needs of our pets Anthropomorphizing our pets can compromise their health according to Dr Sean Delaney a veterinary nutritionist from Davis CA Dr Delaney has gone on record as stating that dogs and cats are evolutionarily hardwired to consume the livestock leave behinds that we find disgusting feet eyes brains etc He further states that these byproducts are quite nutritious for animals Watch a cat eat a mouse and they go for the vital organs because these have the vital nutrients they need as obligate carnivores Unfortunately the ever increasing shift from agrarian to urban population has changed the way society looks at ingredients for pet food often to the detriment of the pet as in the case of imposing a vegan diet on animals that need meat to be healthy n nRegulation of Pet Food and Pet Food Safety n nPet food products are among the most highly regulated products in grocery stores Federal and state laws and regulations apply to various aspects of pet food including ingredients manufacturing processes and labeling Pet food plants are subject to inspection by the FDA and state regulators both state control officials and FDA have the authority to test pet food ingredients and the finished product n nPet food is regulated by the Food and Drug Administration FDA The Federal Food Drug and Cosmetic Act FD C Act requires that all animal foods like human foods be safe to eat produced under sanitary conditions contain no harmful substances and be truthfully labeled In addition canned food must be processed in conformance with the low acid canned food regulations to ensure it is free of viable microorganisms Title Code of Federal Regulations Part n nPet food labeling is regulated at two levels the FDA regulations require proper identification of the product net quantity statement name and place of business of the manufacturer or distributor and proper listing of all the ingredients from most to least based on weight In addition the Association of American Feed Control Officials AAFCO provide a model of regulations that states can follow n nAnimal Sourced Byproducts n nAAFCO s Model Regulations for all animal feeds require that the ingredients list include the species of animal that meat and meat byproducts come from unless the meat or meat byproducts come from cattle swine sheep or goats n nDuring the processing of animals certain parts rejected for human use can be expected to be processed into animal feed This could be meat that doesn t meet human aesthetics or internal organs Meat and meat by products from animals that have diets by other means than slaughter aren t directly suitable for animal food because they are considered adulterated They can t be used for animal feed unless they contain no chemical additives are heat treated and further processed This means that the claims by some so called pet nutritionists that dog food contains roadkill or euthanized animals is bogus disinformation n nSupply Chain Issues n nAmericans are currently experiencing what happens when there are supply chain disruptions to our food supply There are empty shelves and some basic food items simply are not available This is happening whether it is food for ourselves or food for Fluffy and Fido n nIt is easy to see how pet food is impacted Walk down the pet food aisle of grocery stores and pet food stores and you ll notice feet upon feet of empty shelves Some stores have chosen to spread out food on the shelves to make it less apparent but the fact is there s a lot of pet food missing n nCauses of Supply Chain Issues Starting in and Ongoing n nCOVID and COVID policies wreaked havoc on the world in Shutdowns and lockdowns as well as other regulations created a perfect storm of supply chain failure No sector has been left untouched from shortages of containers and trucks to move them empty containers stuck in ports and vessels waiting offshore for weeks to offload their cargo Then there were surging thefts of container cargo Once products are unloaded truck carriers are facing driver shortages and railways are overwhelmed in some areas became the year of the supply chain disruption and it s continuing into n nHow is Pet Food Impacted n nThe pet food industry mirrors the main economy Dana Brooks President of the Pet Food Institute noted recently Manufacturers are experiencing challenges in every node of the supply chain from the ingredient sourcing to transportation and employee shortages n nWhen the pandemic first started hospitality firms and other businesses linked to human food production shut down for public safety Manufacturers of pet food lost a key source of their ingredients With the vast majority of the workforce working remotely from home people turned to pets for companionship and more than million households adopted a new pet between March and December of n nEven now two years later pet food manufacturers are still facing ingredient shortages price increases in processing equipment ingredients and especially transportation Then when businesses ramped back up the pet food industry began reeling from labor shortages n nPet Food Ingredients in Short Supply n nWith pet food ingredients in short supply issues with getting aluminum for cans and added pressure are put on to deal with an already low stock of food n n nOur Pets are Important to Us n nOur pets provide companionship affection exercise and entertainment to us and we as owners want the best for them The reality is that dogs and cats belong to the order of Carnivora for a reason They need meat unless a veterinary nutritionist formulates an alternative diet for our dogs The loss of animal agriculture should animal extremists win means we either lose our pets to malnutrition or we would need to let them fend for themselves which is a death sentence too n nWe can t let that happen n nLinks to references can be found in this article on our website
